{"content_type": "text", "parts": ["\ue200summary\ue202Bill Nelson\ue202turn0search8\ue202\ue201\ue200i\ue202turn0image0\ue202turn0image3\ue202turn0image4\ue202turn0image11\ue201\n\n\ue203Bill Nelson is an American politician and attorney who has dedicated nearly five decades to public service.\ue204 \ue203Born on September 29, 1942, in Miami, Florida, he earned a B.A. in political science from Yale University in 1965 and a J.D. from the University of Virginia School of Law in 1968.\ue204 \ue203He served in the U.S. Army Reserve from 1965 to 1971, achieving the rank of captain.\ue204\n\n\ue203Nelson&#x27;s political career began in the Florida House of Representatives, where he served from 1973 to 1979.\ue204 \ue203He then represented Florida&#x27;s 9th and 11th congressional districts in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1979 to 1991.\ue204 \ue203In 1986, while serving in Congress, he flew aboard the Space Shuttle Columbia (STS-61C) as a payload specialist, becoming the second sitting member of Congress to travel into space.\ue204 \ue200cite\ue202turn0search2\ue201\n\n\ue203After an unsuccessful bid for governor in 1990, Nelson was elected as Florida&#x27;s treasurer, insurance commissioner, and fire marshal in 1994, serving until 2000.\ue204 \ue203He then served three terms in the U.S. Senate from 2001 to 2019, focusing on space policy, climate change, and consumer protection.\ue204 \ue203In 2021, President Joe Biden appointed him as the 14th administrator of NASA, a position he currently holds.\ue204 \ue200cite\ue202turn0search9\ue201\n\n\ue203In his role as NASA administrator, Nelson oversees the agency&#x27;s missions and initiatives, including the Artemis program, which aims to return humans to the Moon and eventually send astronauts to Mars.\ue204 \ue203He continues to advocate for space exploration and technological advancement.\ue204\n\n\ue203For more detailed information about Bill Nelson&#x27;s career and contributions, you can visit his official NASA biography.\ue204 \ue200cite\ue202turn0search9\ue201 "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, It&#x27;s particularly useful if you want to edit the audio by editing the text transcript. They offer a free trial, and then you can choose a subscription plan if you like the service.\n\n3. **Sonix**: This is another automatic transcription service known for its accuracy and ease of use. Sonix offers a pay-per-use model, which might be beneficial if you only need transcription services occasionally.\n\n4. **Rev**: Rev offers both automated and human transcription services. The automated service is cheaper and faster, while the human transcription service provides higher accuracy. You can choose based on your needs and budget.\n\n5. **Temi**: Like Rev, Temi offers automated transcription services at competitive rates. It\u2019s fast and fairly accurate for clear, well-recorded audio.\n\n6. **Trint**: Trint is another automatic transcription service that provides quick and easy transcriptions. It offers a web-based editor for cleaning up transcripts after they have been processed.\n\n7. **Dragon Naturally Speaking**: This is a bit different as it&#x27;s primarily a speech recognition software that you can train to your voice, but it can also be used for transcribing pre-recorded audio files.\n\nWhen choosing a transcription software, consider factors like the audio quality of your recordings, your budget, and whether you need additional features like editing tools or multi-speaker recognition. It&#x27;s user-friendly and quite accurate for clear, well-spoken English.\n\n2. **Google Docs Voice Typing**: While this is primarily for live dictation, you can play your audio file near your microphone and let Google Docs transcribe it. This method requires manual pauses for longer audio and can vary in accuracy based on sound quality and background noise.\n\n3. **Bear File Converter**: This is an online service that offers free transcription for shorter audio files. It uses the same speech recognition technology as many other services but has a limit on the length and size of files you can convert.\n\n4. **Transcriber for WhatsApp**: Although designed for transcribing WhatsApp voice messages, this app can be used for other short audio files if you can get them into your phone&#x27;s voice notes.\n\n5. **OTranscribe**: A free web app designed to streamline the manual transcription process. It doesn&#x27;t automatically transcribe for you, but provides an integrated environment to make manual transcription easier and faster.\n\n6. **Speechnotes**: A free, browser-based service that is good for quick transcriptions. It\u2019s designed more for dictation, but you could play your recorded audio back into the microphone to transcribe it.\n\nWhen using free services, especially ones that utilize live dictation methods (like Google Docs Voice Typing), the accuracy of the transcription can heavily depend on the quality of the recording and the clarity of speech. Also, be mindful of privacy and data security when using online services with sensitive or personal information. Always review the terms and privacy policies of these platforms to ensure they meet your needs and expectations."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": "e048b550-cede-4ef8-9320-2e211f772b52"}}, "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "request_id": "86078d1e8f26a265-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "6665c74a-e3b0-4b17-9235-1662d91ab12c", "children": ["60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80"]}, "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80": {"id": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "message": {"id": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "chat_consensus_app__jit_plugin.search_papers", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709782727.806192, "update_time": 1709782693.1934514, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Psychological impact of fear-based messages in context of COVID 19&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Dear Editor, COVID-19 has emerged as public health crises all around the globe. This unprecedented time call for optimum use of effective health messaging from various sources. Both official communication and media intended to provide information and guidance to the public but the impact of social media and print media is deeper. Messages on social media largely utilise fear-based messages (FBM) to ensure public compliance. Therefore, it is imperative to understand how FBM influences the psyche. Researchers have suggested the cautious use of FBM as it may be ineffective owing to its low efficacy and optimism bias of people around. During the outbreak of Ebola, fear-related behaviours like limited health services utilisation, migration, stigma, and discrimination, blaming and attacking health workers played an important role in the progression of the outbreak. These fear-related behaviours contributed significantly to morbidity and mortality (Shultz et al., 2016). Exposure to Ebola was potentially traumatic considering a high mortality rate, in comparison, fear-related behaviours in context of covid-19 which cannot be explained by illness. Newspapers frequently sensationalise new clusters as \u2018corona blast\u2019. Animations depicting \u2018corona virus\u2019 as a monster are frequently seen. The frequent appearance of images of dead bodies and graveyards can fuel biased interpretation. Exposure to such fear based messages in the absence of other reliable information can lead to a biased conclusion that corona kills everyone. Psychological response is significantly influenced by type and amount of media exposure. Social media messages amplify their effect through \u2018echo chamber\u2019 or \u2018illusion of truth effect\u2019 (Van den Broucke, 2020). Moreover, continuous exposure to COVID related information and denial messages can also lead to bias in estimating threat accurately. Corona Denial messages from authorities or government agencies can also contribute to mistrust and thus result into noncompliance with behavioural measures (Bavel et al., 2020). FBM can be a significant contributor towards cases of suicide reported across the world (Thakur &amp; Jain, 2020). Many individuals suspected for COVID or asymptomatic patients are expressing severe health anxiety or contemplating suicide due to fear of stigma and discrimination. People are also avoiding hospital visits for non-COVID morbidities timely. Fear has become an important governing factor even for health care. Other fear-related behaviours like panic migration, hoarding essentials due to \u2018Zero-sum thinking\u2019 are frequently observed (Bavel et al., 2020; Ventriglio et al., 2020). Fear can elicit the phenomenon of knowledge resistance and misinterpretations (Van den Broucke, 2020). It may also lead to minimising or denial that is, people don\u2019t believe in the plausibility of a message and adopt desired behaviour changes. FBM can also induce guilt and shame contributing to stigma and suicidality. Threat appeals are shown to be effective only when they are coupled with self-efficacy enhancing message. Response to fear can be understood by \u2018Extended Parallel Process Model\u2019 in which perception of threat and self-efficacy is important components. High perception of threat and low perceived self-efficacy can initiate maladaptive behaviours (Carey &amp; Sarma, 2016). Precautionary information with reassurance has a greater impact on behaviour change by enhancing the selfefficacy (Ruiter et al., 2001). Enabling people to make an informed decision can enhance the feelings of social responsibility towards a collective behavioural change (Stolow et al., 2020). Guideline for media reporting should be formulated in conjunction with recommendations for health promotion during a pandemic (Van den Broucke, 2020; Ventriglio et al., 2020). The negative impact of a disproportionate threat should be highlighted by media. Researchers should examine impact of such FBM and corona denial messages during pandemic and post pandemic.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Swami&quot;,&quot;Tanu Gupta&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;International Journal of Social Psychiatry&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/impact-fearbased-messages-context-covid-swami/9f125d8f625158d4a3a6378a1f5a12fd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0020764020980773&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;67&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1081 - 1082&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Crime, News and Fear of Crime: Toward an Identification of Audience Effects&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Communication studies increasingly recognize the audience&#x27;s critical role in receiving and interpreting media messages. Research into audience attributes that distinguish \u201cmedia effects,\u201d on the fear of crime (FEAR) has been limited\u2014particularly as it relates to the reception of news. This study is based on a survey of 2,092 adults in Tallahassee, Florida at the height of a media driven \u201cpanic\u201d about violent crime. Controlling for age, gender, race, victim experience and other perceptions of crime, the frequency of watching television news and listening to news on the radio is significantly related to FEAR. Reading newspapers and newsmagazines and recall of detail concerning specific highly publicized violent crimes are unrelated to FEAR. When audiences are disaggregated by gender, race, and a series of third attributes, television news consumption is significantly related to FEAR only for white females between the ages of thirty and fifty-four. This finding holds regardless of victim experience, income or perceived safety. Several explanations derived from previous research are applied to this finding. Both \u201cresonance\u201d and \u201csubstitution\u201d have possible explanatory relevance, but the \u201caffinity\u201d of audience members with victims most often seen on television news may best account for the concentration of \u201cmedia effects\u201d among white women.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Ted Chiricos&quot;,&quot;Sarah Eschholz&quot;,&quot;Marc G. Gertz&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1997,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social Problems&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/crime-news-fear-crime-toward-identification-audience-chiricos/2137540bc7fd5e8a8e5603560d5b6367/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/3097181&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;44&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;342-357&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Viruses Going Viral: Impact of Fear-Arousing Sensationalist Social Media Messages on User Engagement&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Social media presents a promising yet competitive communication landscape for health practitioners and organizations during the rapid spread of an emerging infectious disease. The current study examined the association between the level of fear-arousing sensationalism and user engagement in 800 Facebook posts regarding the 2016 Zika virus outbreak. Results revealed that the majority of nonnews posts completely lacked sensationalist elements, and that user engagement increased significantly as the level of fear-arousing sensationalism increased from low levels. We discuss the potential value of message design that can engender an appropriate level of public concern and increase user engagement on social media.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;K. Ali&quot;,&quot;Khawaja Zain-ul-abdin&quot;,&quot;Cong Li&quot;,&quot;Lisa Johns&quot;,&quot;A. Ali&quot;,&quot;Nick Carcioppolo&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Science Communication&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/viruses-going-viral-impact-feararousing-sensationalist-ali/4898167e114b593a985587a3cd9cffd5/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/1075547019846124&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;41&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;314 - 338&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;How Fear-Arousing News Messages Affect Risk Perceptions and Intention to Talk About Risk&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT Building on the theoretical arguments of the impersonal-impact and differential-impact hypotheses, this study has a twofold purpose: first, to demonstrate how fear-arousing media messages about risk are associated with personal-level risk perception, as well as, and perhaps more so than, societal-level risk perception; and second, to examine how the resulting risk perceptions can mediate intention to talk about the risk with family and friends. A news message evaluation study was conducted among the general public in South Korea concerning two major risks, carcinogens and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE). Two sets of structural equation models reveal three main findings: (a) Fear-arousing news messages are positively related to personal-level risk perception, as well as to societal-level risk perception; (b) fear-arousing news messages result in intention to talk about the risk directly and indirectly through risk perception; and (c) personal-level risk perception appears more strongly related to intention to talk than does societal-level risk perception, although such relationships may vary across risk topics.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Paek&quot;,&quot;Sang-Hwa Oh&quot;,&quot;Thomas Hove&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2016,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Health Communication&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-news-messages-affect-risk-perceptions-paek/200b0ee7e04155ab9800282907d9f947/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/10410236.2015.1037419&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1051 - 1062&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Fear, threat and efficacy in threat appeals: message involvement as a key mediator to message acceptance.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In a sample of 170 youngsters, the effect of two versions of a public service announcement (PSA) threat appeal against speeding, placed in four different contexts, on evoked fear, perceived threat (severity and probability of occurrence), perceived response efficacy and self-efficacy, message involvement and anti-speeding attitude and anti-speeding intention is investigated. Evoked fear and perceived threat and efficacy independently influence message involvement. Message involvement is a full mediator between evoked fear, perceived threat and efficacy perception on the one hand, and attitudes towards the message and behavioral intention to accept the message on the other. Speeding experience has a significantly negative impact on anti-speeding attitudes. Message and medium context threat levels and context thematic congruency have a significant effect on evoked fear and to a lesser extent on perceived threat.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Verolien Cauberghe&quot;,&quot;Patrick De Pelsmacker&quot;,&quot;W. Janssens&quot;,&quot;Nathalie Dens&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2009,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Accident; analysis and prevention&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fear-threat-efficacy-threat-appeals-message-mediator-cauberghe/fe25a7675837531cbbf1483640ed4de9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.aap.2008.11.006&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;41 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          276-85\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Threat and fear: Pragmatic purposes of emotionalisation in media discourse&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The impact of mass media on individuals and society is to a great extent based on emotions. We concentrate on fear as it is one of the basic emotions triggered by risk and threat, which is claimed to play a key role in the twenty-first century consciousness (Furedi 20018). The study focuses on the emotionalisation of fear in contemporary media discourse about Russia, more specifically, on constructions of Russian threat and fear of Russia in Anglo-American media texts to highlight pragmatic effects and to speculate on possible purposes of such discourses. The study aims to explore the functioning of the lexemes threat and fear , in textual contexts with the focus on their pragma-discursive characteristics. It identifies the mechanisms as well as linguistic tools involved in media strategies of scare-mongering. The dataset was derived from quality British and American newspapers in the period 2018-2020, and was analysed drawing on an interdisciplinary approach combining critical discourse analysis, pragmatics, medialinguistics, psycholinguistics and the theory of proximisation. The paper argues that appealing to emotions as well as constructing emotions is aimed at enhancing the persuasive function of media and fulfilling their own agenda. The persistent use of the words threat and fear in relation to Russia as well as the obsessive discussion of this topic in media aim to shape a certain negative public opinion of Russia among readerships. The findings show that to achieve this goal different strategies and linguistic tools are used including: exaggeration, repetition, proximisation, interrogative headlines, presupposition, among others. The results go beyond linguistics, and may find implementation in political studies, since they provide researchers with tools for understanding contemporary social and political processes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Vladimir I. Ozymenko&quot;,&quot;T. Larina&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2021,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Russian Journal of Linguistics&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/threat-purposes-emotionalisation-media-discourse-ozymenko/6d103211012355a0851da784b568536f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.22363/2687-0088-2021-25-3-746-766&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Investigating mediated effects of fear of COVID-19 and COVID-19 misunderstanding in the association between problematic social media use, psychological distress, and insomnia&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;\\n Introduction\\n Due to the serious situation of the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) worldwide, many countries have implemented policies to minimize the spread of COVID-19 infection. However, some of these policies prevent people from physical contact. Consequently, many individuals may rely on social media to obtain information concerning COVID-19. Unfortunately, social media use (especially problematic social media use) may give rise to psychological distress. Therefore, this study thus examined potential psychopathology to explain the association between problematic social media use, psychological distress, and insomnia.\\n \\n Methods\\n Utilizing an online survey, a sample of Iranian young adults (n=1078 with 628 males; mean age=26.24 years [SD\u00b17.41]) completed questions and psychometric scales concerning psychological distress, insomnia, problematic social media use, fear of COVID-19, and COVID-19 misunderstanding.\\n \\n Results\\n Problematic social media use was significantly associated with psychological distress both directly and indirectly. The indirect effects were through fear of COVID-19 (unstandardized coefficient [B]=0.177; Bootstrapping SE=0.026) and COVID-19 misunderstanding (B=0.060; Bootstrapping SE=0.014). Problematic social media use was significantly associated with insomnia both directly and indirectly. The indirect effect was through fear of COVID-19 (B=0.062; Bootstrapping SE=0.019) but not COVID-19 misunderstanding (B=0.012; Bootstrapping SE=0.014).\\n \\n Discussion/Conclusion\\n Due to the pressure of the COVID-19 outbreak, individuals are highly likely to develop psychological distress and insomnia. Self-effects are the effects of messages the cognitions, emotions, attitudes, and behaviors of the message creators/senders themselves. A total of 4 theories have tried to explain self-effects in offline environments: self-persuasion, self-concept change, expressive writing, and political deliberation. The article reviews research into online self-effects that evolved from each of these theories, and argues why self-effects may be stronger online than offline. Based on this review, a model is introduced that helps explain how online self- and reception effects may coalesce and amplify each other. Media discourses regarding terrorist acts raise questions about how such rhetoric elicits fear in people who typically experience such events through news reports. However, we do not fully understand the impact of the media on perceptions of terrorism as clearly as we understand the relationship between the media and fear of crime. This study examines how media sources accessed actively (e.g. through newspapers; Internet) or passively (e.g. through television; radio) influence knowledge and fear of terrorism. We find receiving information about terrorism from multiple media sources increases fear of terrorism, but media sources accessed passively are not as influential as media sources accessed more actively. These results highlight how media consumption from various sources may affect one\u2019s fear of terrorism, and further illustrates how the role of perceived knowledge may exacerbate or mitigate fear. Symbols in mass communications can be manipulated in a variety of ways so as to arouse socially acquired motives such as need for achievement, group conformity, power-seeking, and the more emotion-laden drives arising from aggression, sympathy, guilt, and anxiety. The present experiment was designed to study the effects of one particular type of motive-incentive variable in persuasive communications, namely, the arousal of fear or anxiety by depicting potential dangers to which the audience might be exposed. Fear appeals of this sort are frequently used to influence attitudes and behavior. For example, medical authorities sometimes try to persuade people to visit cancer detection clinics by pointing to the dangerous consequences of failing to detect the early symptoms of cancer; various political groups play up the threat of war or totalitarianism in an attempt to motivate adherence to their political program. Our interest in such attempts is primarily that of determining the conditions under which the arousal of fear is effective or ineffective in eliciting changes in beliefs, practices, and attitudes. Implicit in the use of fear appeals is the assumption that when emotional tension is aroused, the audience will become more highly motivated to accept the reassuring beliefs or recommendations advocated by the 1 This study was conducted at Yale University as part of a coordinated program of research on attitude and opinion change, financed by a grant from the Rockefeller Foundation. Janis&quot;,&quot;S. Feshbach&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1953,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of abnormal psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-communications-janis/aa74cc610d4d5611a325937f3e1d63e6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/H0060732&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;48 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          78-92\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Appealing to fear: A meta-analysis of fear appeal effectiveness and theories.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Fear appeals are a polarizing issue, with proponents confident in their efficacy and opponents confident that they backfire. We present the results of a comprehensive meta-analysis investigating fear appeals&#x27; effectiveness for influencing attitudes, intentions, and behaviors. We tested predictions from a large number of theories, the majority of which have never been tested meta-analytically until now. Studies were included if they contained a treatment group exposed to a fear appeal, a valid comparison group, a manipulation of depicted fear, a measure of attitudes, intentions, or behaviors concerning the targeted risk or recommended solution, and adequate statistics to calculate effect sizes. The meta-analysis included 127 articles (9% unpublished) yielding 248 independent samples (NTotal = 27,372) collected from diverse populations. Results showed a positive effect of fear appeals on attitudes, intentions, and behaviors, with the average effect on a composite index being random-effects d = 0.29. Moderation analyses based on prominent fear appeal theories showed that the effectiveness of fear appeals increased when the message included efficacy statements, depicted high susceptibility and severity, recommended one-time only (vs. repeated) behaviors, and targeted audiences that included a larger percentage of female message recipients. Overall, we conclude that (a) fear appeals are effective at positively influencing attitude, intentions, and behaviors; (b) there are very few circumstances under which they are not effective; and (c) there are no identified circumstances under which they backfire and lead to undesirable outcomes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Melanie B. However, less is known how social media consumption may influence individuals&#x27; levels of fear. Research indicates that messages utilizing fear (fear-based messages or FBMs) can significantly affect the public&#x27;s psychological state. Although such messages are often intended to inform or guide public behavior, they can lead to unintended consequences, such as increased anxiety, stigmatization, and even non-compliance with beneficial measures due to mistrust or fear fatigue. Here are some key insights from relevant research:\n\n1. **Psychological Impact of Fear-Based Messaging**: Fear-based messages can induce fear-related behaviors, such as avoidance of health services, stigma, discrimination, and non-compliance with public guidelines. Continuous exposure to such messages can lead to biased interpretations and overestimations of threats, significantly influencing psychological responses [(Swami &amp; Gupta, 2020)](https://consensus.app/papers/impact-fearbased-messages-context-covid-swami/9f125d8f625158d4a3a6378a1f5a12fd/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Media and Fear of Crime**: The frequency of consuming media, especially television news, has been found to correlate significantly with fear, particularly among certain demographics. This relationship suggests that media consumption can amplify fears about crime and safety [(Chiricos, Eschholz, &amp; Gertz, 1997)](https://consensus.app/papers/crime-news-fear-crime-toward-identification-audience-chiricos/2137540bc7fd5e8a8e5603560d5b6367/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Social Media and Fear**: Platforms like Facebook have been observed to increase user engagement with posts that contain fear-arousing sensationalist content. This can indicate that social media amplifies the impact of fear-based messaging, affecting public concern and engagement with issues [(Ali et al., 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/viruses-going-viral-impact-feararousing-sensationalist-ali/4898167e114b593a985587a3cd9cffd5/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n4. **Impact of Fear on Behavior and Perception**: Fear-arousing news messages have been shown to increase personal-level risk perception more than societal-level risk perception. This heightened perception of personal risk can lead to increased discussions about risks and potentially change behavior and attitudes [(Paek, Oh, &amp; Hove, 2016)](https://consensus.app/papers/feararousing-news-messages-affect-risk-perceptions-paek/200b0ee7e04155ab9800282907d9f947/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n5. **Fear and Media Discourse**: The emotionalization of fear in media discourse, particularly in relation to perceived threats (like from specific countries or groups), aims to enhance media&#x27;s persuasive function and may fulfill particular agendas by shaping public opinion and perceptions [(Ozymenko &amp; Larina, 2021)](https://consensus.app/papers/threat-purposes-emotionalisation-media-discourse-ozymenko/6d103211012355a0851da784b568536f/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nIn summary, fear-based messaging in the media, whether relating to public health, crime, or other perceived threats, can significantly affect the public&#x27;s attitudes, behaviors, and perceptions. While these messages might aim to inform and protect the public, they can also lead to heightened anxiety, stigma, and a skewed perception of risk.\n\nFor more AI-powered insights, go to [consensus.app](https://consensus.app/?utm_source=chatgpt)."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "parent_id": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "request_id": "86078d1e8f26a265-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "60662c1e-3a9c-48ca-88ee-da3de2b14f80", "children": ["aaa25197-aec7-4b91-9b15-16aa390a01ff"]}, "aaa25197-aec7-4b91-9b15-16aa390a01ff": {"id": "aaa25197-aec7-4b91-9b15-16aa390a01ff", "message": {"id": "aaa25197-aec7-4b91-9b15-16aa390a01ff", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709782819.079778, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["How many unsanctioned CIA operations around the world have been exposed since the CIA formation? It evolved rapidly into an eclectic, well-resourced organization whose activities provided a substitute for overt military action and afforded essential backup when the Cold War turned hot in Korea and Vietnam. This comprehensive examination of a still controversial subject sheds valuable new light on the undercover operations mounted by the CIA during the Cold War. Using a wide range of unpublished government records and documents, James Callanan traces the growth of the agency chronologically as it forged a covert action mission that sought to advance US foreign and defense policy in all corners of the globe. An award-winning journalist, Angus Mackenzie waged and won a lawsuit against the CIA under the Freedom of Information Act and became a leading expert on questions concerning government censorship and domestic spying. In \\&quot;Secrets\\&quot;, he reveals how federal agencies - including the Department of Defense, the executive branch, and the CIA - have monitored and controlled public access to information. Mackenzie lays bare the behind-the-scenes evolution of a policy of suppression, repression, spying, and harassment. Secrecy operations originated during the Cold War as the CIA instituted programs of domestic surveillance and agent provocateur activities. As antiwar newspapers flourished, the CIA set up an &#x27;underground newspaper&#x27; desk devoted, as Mackenzie reports, to various counterintelligence activities - from infiltrating organizations to setting up CIA-front student groups. Mackenzie also tracks the policy of requiring secrecy contracts for all federal employees who have contact with sensitive information, insuring governmental review of all their writings after leaving government employ. The ISC objectives were global in scope \u2014 to organize the world&#x27;s national student unions into a network that could deny the pro-Soviet International Union of Students its claim to represent the world student population. The CIA&#x27;s reach depended heavily on the US National Student Association, which provided both a rationale for funding flows from the United States, and a steady stream of personnel. I prefer to focus more broadly on all those activities conducted secretly by intelligence agency officials fearful that publicity could compromise fulfillment of a specific mission (recruitment of an agent, precipitation of a coup, investigation into espionage or criminal activities), or their agency&#x27;s recognizably illegal or political activities. It was the president&#x27;s personal action arm - overthrowing governments, bribing heads of state, and plotting assassinations in a global secret war against communism. Within the inner circles of Washington, at the high point of American power in the world, they were regarded as the best and brightest. They planned and acted to contain the Soviet threat, by political action and cunning that armies could not be allowed to be part of. As part of these efforts, the CIA undertook support of Russian exiles, populations uprooted either during World War II or by the Russian Revolution decades before. No one seemed better prepared to fight in the American secret war against communism than the uprooted Russians, whom the CIA directed to carry out propaganda, espionage, and subversion operations from their home base in West Germany. Yet the American engagement of Russian exiles had unpredictable outcomes. Drawing on recently declassified and previously untapped sources, Cold War Exiles and the CIA examines how the CIA\u2019s Russian operations became entangled with the internal struggles of Russia abroad and also the espionage wars of the superpowers in divided Germany. What resulted was a transnational political sphere involving different groups of Russian exiles, American and German anti-communists, and spies operating on both sides of the Iron Curtain. Inadvertently, CIA\u2019s patronage of Russian exiles forged a complex sub-front in the wider Cold War, demonstrating the ways in which the hostilities of the Cold War played out in ancillary conflicts involving proxies and non-state actors.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Benjamin Tromly&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/exiles-tromly/6aebe6161d3c59e7980acefc4794c32d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1093/oso/9780198840404.001.0001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Is sunlight the best counterintelligence technique? the effectiveness of covert operation exposure in blunting the Russian intervention in the 2020 U.S. election&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT In runup to 2020 U.S. elections U.S. intelligence agencies tried to prevent Russian covert operations from affecting the results. Various methods were used including the exposure of detected covert Russian activities. The question of the actual effects of this counterintelligence operation however remains open. This study examines the effects of the exposure strategy on target public using a novel method. I find strong evidence that U.S. intelligence agencies efforts to expose the Russian hand succeeded in blunting the effects of the targeted covert activities. This indicates that the exposure counterintelligence strategy is a potent tool for defanging covert foreign election interference/partisan electoral interventions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Dov H. Levin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Intelligence and National Security&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sunlight-counterintelligence-technique-effectiveness-levin/fbadfe9f9b8a56fea1b73745f9cfc94d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02684527.2023.2181923&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;38&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;816 - 834&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Media technology, covert action, and the politics of exposure&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;States wishing to use force in the modern era frequently face strong incentives to exploit secrecy. Successful covert operations can reduce the likelihood of unwanted escalation with powerful rivals and help leaders conceal unpopular actions from domestic and foreign audiences alike. The many benefits of secrecy, however, can only be realized if covert operations remain covert. We argue that access to information and communications technologies (ICTs) is a critical factor that increases the chances that a covert mission will be exposed. As a result, leaders are much less likely to reach for the quiet option when a potential target has dense ICT networks. We illustrate our mechanism through US national security archival vignettes. We test our argument using a dataset of declassified US military and electoral interventions intended to subvert incumbent regimes throughout the Cold War. The core finding, that leaders are less likely to pursue covert action relative to alternative options when the chances of exposure are high, holds across five distinct measures of ICT networks as well as different model specifications and placebo tests. Our findings suggest that Cold War-style covert operations may well be a thing of the past in an age where communication and media technologies have proliferated to the far corners of the globe. We advance debates on communications technologies, covert action, and political violence.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Michael F Joseph&quot;,&quot;Michael Poznansky&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Peace Research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/media-technology-action-politics-exposure-joseph/78d50b0184cc502181e7c34d3cde5b15/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0022343317731508&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;320 - 335&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;\u2018The Sun Never Sets on the Activities of the CIA\u2019: Project Resistance at William and Mary&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract This article examines the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) on the campus of the College of William and Mary in 1969 and 1970. Although the CIA operation at William and Mary was first revealed in 1980, it has not received any scholarly attention. The CIA compiled information on students and faculty who were perceived to be radical. The CIA utilized informants working in the Office of the Dean of Men. In gathering information about students and professors, CIA officials violated the law and undermined academic freedom. The surveillance serves as a reminder of how easily a secret agency can threaten civil liberties and demonstrates why Congress must be vigilant in its oversight of the intelligence establishment.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. McCarthy&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Intelligence and National Security&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/never-sets-activities-project-resistance-william-mary-mccarthy/fc885b5915685f3ca3b593713ce639f1/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02684527.2012.699291&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;28&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;611 - 633&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;CIA (Central Intelligence Agency) Covert Action in Zaire and Angola: Patterns and Consequences&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;\\&quot;Covert action\\&quot; as practiced by the United States Central Intelligence Agency has been defined as \\&quot;clandestine activity designed to influence foreign governments, events, organizations or persons in support of U.S. foreign policy conducted in such a way that the involvement of the U.S. Government is not apparent.\\&quot;1 The CIA has pursued its most substantial African covert actions in Zaire (the former Belgian Congo) and Angola. As the paramilitary, political, and propaganda operation unfolded in Angola in 19751976, both U.S. policymakers and distressed African observers were struck by its connection to earlier American intervention in Zaire. Secretary of State Henry Kissinger suggested that Angolan independence was fraught with the same dangers for U.S. security as Zairian independence in 1960: \\&quot;We cannot ignore, for example, the substantial Soviet build-up of weapons in Angola, which has introduced great power rivalry into Africa for the first time in 15 years.\\&quot;2 Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs William Schaufele, Jr., discerned \\&quot;obvious parallels between Soviet efforts to move in on the Congo after independence in&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Weissman&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1979,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Political Science Quarterly&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intelligence-agency-covert-action-zaire-angola-patterns-weissman/980d2a2bd59957ff8048951b15ebd35f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/2149851&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;94&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;263-286&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The CIA &amp; the cult of secrecy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;PAGE This dissertation re-conceptualizes the scandals that engulfed the intelligence community in the mid-1970s. The Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) confronted an unprecedented crisis during these years: the Pike hearings in the House of Representatives, the Church Committee in the Senate, and an executive branch commission led by then Vice President Nelson Rockefeller. Historians and political scientists have studied these events before, but I present a nuanced interpretation of the intelligence investigations by placing them in a broader political and cultural context. To fully understand the impact of the so-called \\&quot;Year of Intelligence,\\&quot; I argue that scholars need to focus on what was happening outside of Congress. The CIA encountered a backlash from both ends of the political spectrum. I provide the first history of Counter-Spy, a left wing magazine founded in 1973 that called for the abolition of covert action. The magazine&#x27;s editors directly challenged the \\&quot;culture of secrecy\\&quot; at the CIA by publishing the names of Agency operatives. At the same time, conservatives embarked on a very different confrontation with the Agency. Like CounterSpy, they charged that the CIA was keeping secrets from the American people, but their concern was with Agency analysis of the Soviet Union, not covert action. I also examine Hollywood portrayals of the CIA in this tumultuous era; rather than simply responding to the Congressional investigations and the Rockefeller Commission, filmmakers actually anticipated the widespread concerns about the complex relationship between espionage and democracy. The events of the mid-1970s badly tarnished the CIA&#x27;s image. In response to this rapid decline in popular support, the Agency developed an aggressive public relations campaign designed to restore confidence in government secrecy and covert operations. This dissertation contains the first systematic history of CIA public relations. The public relations staff has consistently portrayed the CIA as the most open intelligence agency in the world, heroically protecting national security while accepting the necessity of Congressional oversight. But despite these public statements, Agency officials worked to revitalize the \\&quot;culture of secrecy.\\&quot; They have dramatically restricted the ability of former employees to write critically about CIA activities; they have successfully lobbied Congress for exemptions to the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA); and they have repeatedly broken promises to de-classify historical records. Agency officials have been obsessed with protecting their image, and this obsession has frequently undermined historical research. Robert M. Gates launched an openness initiative in February 1992, but the culture at the Agency was not fundamentally changed. In fact, George Tenet shut down the voluntary de-classification program at the CIA in 1998. A key conclusion of this study is that the \\&quot;culture of secrecy\\&quot; at the Agency remains firmly entrenched. Since the CIA cannot be reformed from within, I argue that outside intervention is required.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Italian \u2018Stay-Behind\u2019 network \u2013 The origins of operation \u2018Gladio\u2019&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract This essay is based on an analysis of the official documentation made available to the Italian Parliamentary Commissions of Inquiry on the origins and development of the stay-behind network in Italy. It tries to use these materials and integrate them with those of historical research on some related subjects in order to sketch out a tentative outline of the chronology and of the reasons for the creation of \u2018Gladio\u2019, as the stay-behind network was officially denominated. The article concludes that the documents released to the Parliamentary Committees do not permit the assumption that Operation \u2018Gladio\u2019 was involved in any illegal activities connected with the terrorism of the late 1960s and of the 1970s. The documents, in other words, do not help solving any of the mysteries which beleaguered Italian post-war history for more than a decade. The document, dated 1 June 1959, had been compiled by the Italian military secret service SIFAR and is entitled \u201cThe special forces of SIFAR and Operation Gladio\u201d. It explained that a secret stay-behind army linked to NATO had been set up in Italy for the purpose of unconventional warfare. Communists claimed that the clandestine organisation had operated to prevent a legal accession to power by the Left. The Venetian police magistrate, Felice Casson, who uncovered the secret network and others have raised questions about its possible connection with some of the unsolved acts of terrorism which afflicted Italy between 1969 and 1984.2 Bettino Craxi, who did not learn of the existence of Gladio until a year after he became premier in 1983, has asked \u2018Did it turn away from its original aims of national defence? Were members of it linked to the terrorist destruction?\u2018.3 His concerns were echoed by the Republican leader Giorgio La Malfa, who asked \u2018Could there be a connection between this structure and the tension, the killings, the deaths, the wounds inflicted on Italian life in the 1960s and 1970s until the beginning of the 1980s?\u2018.4 These concerns and the information that is available to the public concerning Gladio must be evaluated in the context of post-war Italian history. The intervention of the United States in internal Italian politics has been blatant and the dominant Christian Democrats from the beginning cast their lot with the United States. In the first three months of the crucial election year of 1948, the United States provided Italy with $176 million, but warned that aid would immediately be terminated if the Left was victorious at the polls. If the Italian voters did not allow themselves to be bought, the United States was ready to support an insurrection by providing underground groups with money and military assistance. The American Mediterranean fleet was strengthened; U.S. warships were dispatched to Italy\u2019s main ports; and preparations were made for a direct occupation of Sicily and Sardinia.s The Left, however, was defeated, and the Christian Democrats, who continued to receive American financial largess, played the role of docile clients. Though the post-war Italian armed forces amounted to no more than a token entity, Italy, primarily for political and strategic considerations, was brought into NATO at its inception in 1949. With the outbreak of the Korean War, the United States hastily equipped the Italian military with American ordinance. According to one of Andreotti\u2019s renditions, Gladio was formed in 1951 amid the tense climate engendered by the Korean War.6 William Colby, who served at the Rome CIA office and who directed the CIA between 1973 and 1976, has stated that the United States played a central role in setting up this \u2018secret army\u2019.\u2019&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. EnglishDuring the Cold War, Stay-Behind was a clandestine network connected to NATO whose mission would have been to act behind enemy lines in the event of a Soviet invasion. Since the invasion never took place, this network never acted and its existence would have remained hidden if the president of the Italian government, Giulio Andreotti, had not disclosed it in 1990. The Italian branch of Stay-Behind was known as Gladio and, although judicial and parliamentary inquiries have not found any evidence of its involvement in criminal activities, a conspiracy theory that maintains its responsabilty in the terrorism of the \u201clead years\u201d has been spread. The study is based on three novels (La Compagnia dei Celestini, Elianto, Spiriti) in which readers can easily find and recognise various traits of today\u2019s Italy hidden behind different names, such as Gladonia, Tristalia or Usitalia \u2013 traits so strongly rooted in reality that they cannot be ignored. The range of allusions to Italy is vast indeed: from politics to the city of Rimini, from passion for television, through consumption, to traffic jams. Additionally, the paper points out that these descriptions can be seen as chronicles of Italy; in fact, the analysis of Benni\u2019s books displays changes which the country underwent over time, from the early Nineties to the New Millennium. Even if Benni draws the images of Italy which can sometimes seem distorted or exaggerated, they are always very close to reality. Spinola&quot;,&quot;Alex Turner&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Papers of the British School at Rome&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/lateran-project-interim-report-january-2014-season-rome-haynes/f69f2ccbb6755e239863aeab1c65073f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S0068246214000166&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;82&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;331 - 335&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The AVI project: A bibliographical and archive inventory of landslides and floods in Italy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The AVI project was commissioned by the Minister of Civil Protection to the National Group for Prevention of Hydrogeologic Hazards to complete an inventory of areas historically affected by landslides and floods in Italy. More than 300 people, divided into 15 research teams and two support groups, worked for one year on the project. Twenty-two journals were systematically searched for the period 1918\u20131990, 350,000 newspaper issues were screened, and 39,953 articles were collected. About 150 experts on mass movement and floods were interviewed and 1482 published and unpublished technical and scientific reports were reviewed. The results of the AVI project, in spite of the limitations, represent the most comprehensive archiving of mass movement and floods ever prepared in Italy. The type and quality of the information collected and the methodologies and techniques used to make the inventory are discussed. Possible applications and future developments are also presented.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Guzzetti&quot;,&quot;M. Cardinali&quot;,&quot;P. In particular, M. gladiata is a serious pest of Ficus microcarpa L. f. (Moraceae), one of the most frequently cultivated ornamental trees in southern Europe. The psyllid was reported for the first time in Europe in 2009, from Spain, and in 2012 it was recorded in Italy, based on its findings on ornamental F. microcarpa trees in Naples town centre. Data here reported on its outbreak presence in many localities in Sicily indicate a dangerous spread over Italy of this noxious psyllid pest.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. The species is diagnosed, illustrated and nomenclature is briefly discussed. Preliminary observations carried out during the period July-November 2011indicated that this species has overlapping generations. A. Pedata&quot;,&quot;D. Burckhardt&quot;,&quot;D. Mancini&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2012,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Bulletin of Insectology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/infestations-jumping-plantlouse-macrohomotoma-gladiata-pedata/f1c1ebfb7c1156fa813bcc3a5f5605f9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;65&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;95-98&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The gladiator reliefs of Italy and broader developments in gladiator imagery&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The museums of central Italy shelter a remarkable collection of reliefs and fragments of reliefs decorated with gladiatorial combats; further pieces are built into the walls of churches and other buildings. Some, such as the friezes from the tomb of C. Lusius Storax at Teate Marrucinorum (Chieti) or the large relief panel from near Pompeii\u2019s Porta Stabia, are well-preserved and well-known; but the majority are fragmentary, some showing no more than a pair of legs or part of a worn figure. M. Flecker\u2019s book, based on an Augsburg dissertation of 2008/9 directed by V. Kockel, sets out to collect and analyse these pieces and to set them in their historical and art-historical contexts. As with many dissertations, the core of the work is a catalogue (chapt. IX, section A), which lists and describes 79 reliefs. Almost all are illustrated, often with excellent photographs from the collection of the DAI Rome; and Flecker has examined a large number of them in person. They include the spectacular blocks from a frieze with nearly-lifesize gladiators recovered from robbers at Fiano Romano and displayed in the museum at Lucus Feroniae, north of Rome (A 34); only preliminary publications of this important discovery have been published to date,1 and it is very welcome that Flecker has been authorised to describe and to illustrate the reliefs fully, even if other elements are not yet published (notably the fragments of an accompanying inscription and a togatus statue). For each entry Flecker gives an oftenextensive bibliography and a detailed description, which concentrates on the categories of gladiator depicted, their equipment and arms, and the iconographic scheme followed. Very few of the reliefs can be dated on an epigraphic basis; these include some atypical examples dating from the 2nd c. A.D., later than the main period covered here. For the rest, Flecker proposes dates based primarily on the Realien (especially the equipment and arms of the gladiators) and on his conception of the overall development of gladiatorial combat, both being discussed in the first part of the book; he concludes that the main period of production falls in the 1st c. B.C. and A.D., with concentration especially in the Caesarian and early to mid-Augustan periods (cf. chart on 180). The majority come from central Italy as far south as Paestum, with a few outliers; only a small number were found in Rome.2&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;K. Dunbabin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Roman Archaeology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/gladiator-reliefs-italy-developments-gladiator-imagery-dunbabin/d9bc241671fc5a9b932777be803c6704/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S1047759418001770&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;694 - 700&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Preliminary Characterization of Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. gladioli Causing Fusarium Corm Rot of Saffron in Italy.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Fusarium corm rot of saffron (Crocus sativus L.), incited by Fusarium oxysporum Schlecht. f. sp. gladioli, causes severe stigma yield losses in L&#x27;Aquila Province in Central Italy. Primary symptoms during flowering (October through November) include basal stem rot, yellowing and wilting of shoots, and corm rot. The rapid spread of the disease is apparently caused only by movement of contaminated and/or infected corms (2,3). Ten isolates of F. oxysporum f. sp. gladioli, obtained from infected saffron crops located in the principal areas of saffron production in L&#x27;Aquila Province (2,3), were characterized by vegetative compatibility tests. The isolates were placed into vegetative compatibility groups (VCGs) using heterokaryon tests with chlorate-resistant nitrate-nonutilizing (nit) mutants. Based on complementation among these isolates and with a representative isolate of VCG 0340 (4), the tested isolates were assigned to VCG 0340. The fact that all isolates examined in this study belong to a single VCG supports the hypothesis that a clonal population of F. oxysporum f. sp. gladioli is spreading in L&#x27;Aquila Province in planting stock. In previous studies, only two Italian isolates of the pathogen obtained from Gladiolus were tested for vegetative compatibility, and both were included in VCG 0343 (1,4). Acquisition of further information on a larger number of isolates obtained from other cropping sites and associated with other hosts may result in a better understanding of the origin and spread of the pathogen in Italy, leading to improved strategies for control of Fusarium corm rot of saffron. References: (1) R. P. Baayen et al. Eur. J. Plant Pathol. 104:887, 1998. (2) C. Cappelli and G. Di Minco. Infitore Fitopatol. 49:27, 1999. (3) C. Cappelli and G. Di Minco. J. Plant Pathol. 80:253, 1998. (4) J. J. Mes et al. Plant Pathol. 43:362, 1994.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Di Primo&quot;,&quot;C. Cappelli&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Plant disease&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/characterization-fusarium-oxysporum-causing-fusarium-primo/a478c6f3fb865895a1656846feb385b7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1094/PDIS.2000.84.7.806C&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;84 7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          806\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The discovery of the school of gladiators at Carnuntum, Austria&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Sophisticated techniques of archaeological survey, including airborne imaging spectroscopy, electromagnetic induction and ground-penetrating radar, are opening up new horizons in the non-invasive exploration of archaeological sites. One location where they have yielded spectacular results is Carnuntum in Austria, on the south bank of the Danube, capital of the key Roman province of Pannonia. Excavations in the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries revealed many of the major elements of this extensive complex, including the legionary fortress and the civilian town or municipium. Excavation, however, is no longer the only way of recovering and recording the details of these buried structures. In 2011, a combination of non-invasive survey methods in the area to the south of the civilian town, where little was visible on the surface, led to the dramatic discovery of remains interpreted as a gladiatorial school, complete with individual cells for the gladiators and a circular training arena. The combination of techniques has led to the recording and visualisation of the buried remains in astonishing detail, and the impact of the discovery is made all the greater by the stunning reconstruction images that the project has generated.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;W. Neubauer&quot;,&quot;Christian Gugl&quot;,&quot;M. Scholz&quot;,&quot;G. Verhoeven&quot;,&quot;I. Trinks&quot;,&quot;K. L\u00f6cker&quot;,&quot;M. Doneus&quot;,&quot;T. Saey&quot;,&quot;M. Meirvenne&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Antiquity&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/school-gladiators-carnuntum-austria-neubauer/441b1ccff03756458e8c9e81dfed1778/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/S0003598X00050298&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;88&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173 - 190&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The fluctuations of italian glaciers during the last century: a contribution to knowledge about alpine glacier changes&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract. This paper describes the recent evolution of Italian glaciers through an analysis of all available terminus fluctuation data that the authors have entered in a glaciers database (named GLAD) containing 883 records collected on glaciers from 1908 to 2002. Furthermore, a representative subset of data (249 glaciers located in Lombardy) was analysed regarding surface area changes. For the analysis of terminus fluctuations, the glaciers were sorted by size classes according to length. The data showed that during the 20th century Italian Alpine glaciers underwent a generalized retreat, with one distinct and well documented readvance episode that occurred between the 1970s and mid\u20101980s, and a poorly documented one around the early 1920s. The rates of terminus advance and retreat have changed without significant delays for the larger glaciers with respect to the smaller ones. However, the smaller the glacier, the more limited the advance (if any) during the 1970s and early 1980s. The behaviour of glaciers shorter than 1 km appears to have changed in the last decade, and between 1993 and 2002 they retreated at a very high rate. The analysis of the subset of data led to a quanti\u2010fication of surface reduction of c. 10% from 1992 to 1999 for glaciers in Lombardy. Small glaciers proved to contribute strongly to total area loss: in 1999, 232 glaciers (c. 90% of the total) were smaller than 1 km2, covering 27.2 km2 (less than 30% of the total area), but accounted for 58% of the total loss in area (they had lost 7.4 km2).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Citterio&quot;,&quot;G. Diolaiuti&quot;,&quot;C. Smiraglia&quot;,&quot;C. D&#x27;agata&quot;,&quot;T. Carnielli&quot;,&quot;G. Stella&quot;,&quot;G. B. Siletto&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2007,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Geografiska Annaler: Series A, Physical Geography&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/fluctuations-glaciers-century-contribution-knowledge-citterio/86f590e24a5b5f11b94fe7d7fa6a4351/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/j.1468-0459.2007.00316.x&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;89&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;167 - 184&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:19},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Satellite radar interferometry and in-situ measurements for static monitoring of historical monuments: The case of Gubbio, Italy&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract The paper presents an overview of the results of diagnostic and monitoring activities carried out in the last years through satellite radar interferometry (2011\u20132016) and in situ measurements (2017\u20132019) in the historical city of Gubbio, Italy. The study is aimed at contributing to understanding the potential of remote sensing technologies in measuring complex deformation phenomena in historic buildings, such as those caused by soil-structural interaction and earthquakes, considering the monumental Consoli Palace and the Town Walls as case studies. The research activities have been carried out within the European HERACLES project, funded in the framework of Horizon (2020) and aimed at proposing novel diagnostic monitoring solutions for enhancing heritage resilience against various types of hazards. Particular attention is focused on the cross-correlation of the outputs of satellite radar interferometry and in-situ structural monitoring data aimed at achieving engineering meaningful results supporting decision making and proactive interventions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;N. Cavalagli&quot;,&quot;Alban Kita&quot;,&quot;S. Falco&quot;,&quot;F. Trillo&quot;,&quot;M. Costantini&quot;,&quot;F. The mission of these networks was to prepare for and act in the event of a Soviet invasion or influence. Although initially intended for defense against foreign invasions, there have been controversies and debates regarding Gladio&#x27;s activities, including alleged involvement in political manipulation and terrorism within Italy.\n\nHere are key findings from scholarly research on Project Gladio in Italy:\n\n1. **Origins and Development**: The Italian &#x27;Stay-Behind&#x27; network, known as Operation &#x27;Gladio&#x27;, was officially denominated and established in the post-World War II period. While documents released to Italian Parliamentary Committees have not definitively connected Gladio to illegal activities or domestic terrorism, they have contributed to understanding Italy&#x27;s foreign and security policies in the aftermath of World War II [(Nuti, 2007)](https://consensus.app/papers/staybehind-network-origins-operation-gladio-nuti/4bbf93e1c2f5591e81159d13b26d6ecd/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **US Covert Intervention**: The Italian stay-behind network has been studied in the context of American covert intervention, exploring broader policymaking and strategic issues. These networks, including Gladio, were part of a larger framework of U.S. efforts to counteract Soviet influence in Italy and other Western countries during the Cold War [(Cacciatore, 2021)](https://consensus.app/papers/staybehind-networks-interim-strategy-gladio-case-cacciatore/d5b426f021d451e68705fdc3983b06f1/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Conspiracy and Terrorism**: There have been numerous allegations linking Gladio to acts of terrorism during the Cold War, especially during Italy&#x27;s &quot;Years of Lead.&quot; Although there is significant debate among researchers, concrete evidence tying Gladio directly to terrorist activities remains inconclusive. However, the existence of the network and its potential for misuse have led to serious concerns and inquiries [(Ganser, 2006)](https://consensus.app/papers/ghost-machiavelli-approach-operation-gladio-terrorism-ganser/c1921f069901502d9eebfbe4b30d7111/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nThese studies provide an understanding of Project Gladio&#x27;s role within the broader context of the Cold War and Italian history. While Gladio was part of a larger NATO strategy, its legacy is intertwined with Italy&#x27;s political and social turbulence during the latter half of the 20th century."]}, "status": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;R &amp; D Cooperation in AI: Report on the U.S. and Japanese panel, IJCAI 1985&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The consensus of government, academic, and industry leaders widely supports the strategic positioning of U.S. and Japanese research and development in mutually beneficial, two-way flows of innovation. This report is derived from the IJCAI panel titled U.S and Japanese Cooperation in AI and R&amp;D Opportunities, held August 23, 1986 at the University of California at Los Angeles. This panel discussed the sensitive topic of alternatives to nationalistic competitive strategies that have contributed to an extreme trade deficit surpassing $40 billion in 1986. The ideas offered by the panelists shed light on ways our countries&#x27; respective scientific communities can blend talents to achieve the best results in reducing trade frictions. Each country has designated AI research as a key to unlock years of generations of technology and has directed billions of dollars to fund this development. The most recognized projects are the U.S. Microelectronics Technology Computer Consortium (MCC) and Japan&#x27;s Fifth Generation Computer Project (ICOT). Although noting the obstacles, the panelists encouraged specific, shared efforts to ensure the development of a closer working relationship to explore AI&#x27;s benefits.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Jacobson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1986,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Ai Magazine&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/cooperation-report-japanese-panel-ijcai-1985-jacobson/e12dd01ae55056ce9c8672907b189f86/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1609/AIMAG.V7I2.539&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;65-69&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Overseas Research: A Practical Guide&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Scholars and students engaged in overseas research projects often spend much of their time worrying about mundane details never reported in published research. In fact, the quality of scholarship often depends on the researcher&#x27;s ability to navigate a bewildering array of social, financial, bureaucratic, and logistical obstacles encountered in preparing for, working in, and recovering from \\&quot;the field.\\&quot; &#x27;Overseas Research: A Practical Guide&#x27; is the first book designed explicitly to prepare scholars and professionals for the real-life challenges of living and working abroad. Opening with a discussion of site selection and project funding, the authors advise researchers on preparing for departure, setting up residence in the field, conducting research in an unfamiliar environment, employing field assistants, and organizing for and adjusting to the return home. The text is supplemented with the insights, anecdotes, and tips from more than sixty scholars in a wide variety of disciplines who conducted research in more than forty countries.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. The descriptive and analytical approach was used to analyze data and information available from various sources, including reports, press articles, and academic research. The results show that China has a competitive advantage in the field of artificial intelligence, thanks to its ambitious national plans and huge investments in this field, and this makes the United States face A big challenge in the competition with China. Among the main challenges facing the United States is the lack of government investment in the field of artificial intelligence, in addition to problems related to privacy and security and the rapid shifts in technology. The research also includes an analysis of some of the opportunities the United States can seize to make further advances in AI, such as increasing government investment, improving education, and strengthening international partnerships. In the end, this research enhances the general understanding of the accelerating transformations in the field of artificial intelligence and helps to identify the necessary measures to enhance the technical and research capabilities of the United States and China in this field, and to identify areas in which one country can obtain a competitive advantage in this field, which contributes to To achieve leadership in this field.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Hazim Jerri Mnekhir&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2023,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Russian Law Journal&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/uschinese-race-artificial-intelligence-challenges-mnekhir/573447f614755fd2a94c5875be73ef64/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.52783/rlj.v11i3.2182&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Internationalization at Home Alternatives to Study Abroad&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Colleges and universities are increasingly internationalizing their curricular and cocurricular efforts on campuses; subsequently, it is important to compare whether internationalization at home activities may be associated with students\u2019 self-reported development of global, international, and intercultural (GII) competencies. This study examined undergraduate students\u2019 participation in study abroad and on-campus global/international activities within nine large public research universities in the United States. Framed within several intercultural development theories, the results of this study suggest that students\u2019 participation in activities related to internationalization at home\u2014participation in on-campus global/international activities such as enrollment in global/international coursework, interactions with international students, and participation in global/international cocurricular activities\u2014may yield greater perceived benefits than study abroad for students\u2019 development of GII competencies.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Krista M. This paper investigates funding by the U.S. National Science Foundation and National Natural Science Foundation of China from 2010 to 2019, including the key institutions and universities that received AI awards, and the key AI disciplines and applications of focus in the research. Comparisons between the U.S. National Science Foundation and the National Natural Science Foundation of China, including the number of published papers as a result of the awards, are also presented.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Hamidreza Habibollahi Najaf Abadi&quot;,&quot;Zhou He&quot;,&quot;M. Some observers view such activities with suspicion, since they regard them as a device to \\&quot;export\\&quot; R and D jobs, or as a channel through which American technology may be transmitted to actual or potential foreign competitors.&#x27; Others, particularly the governments of many developing (and some developed) countries, view them as highly desirable activities that will help to stimulate indigenous R and D in these countries. Indeed, the United Nations Group of Eminent Persons recommended that host countries require multinational corporations to contribute towards innovation of appropriate kinds, and to encourage them to do such R and D in their overseas affiliates.2 Although the amount of controversy in this area might lead one to believe that the nature of existing overseas R and D activities of US-based firms has been studied quite thoroughly, this is far from the case. The unfortunate truth is that economists have devoted little or no attention to even the most basic questions concerning these activities.3 In this paper, we try to fill part of this gap.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Mansfield&quot;,&quot;D. Teece&quot;,&quot;A. Romeo&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1980,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The International Executive&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/research-development-us\u2010based-firms-mansfield/55ff538601f0500e97611f9d592de34f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/TIE.5060220106&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;22&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;10-12&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Study Abroad Experiences and Global Citizenship&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Short-term study abroad programs currently account for more than 50% of students who study overseas. Using an adaptation of the Value\u2013Belief\u2013Norm theory of proenvironmental behavior (Stern, 2000), we hypothesized that study abroad nurtures global citizenship related to ecologically conscious behaviors by strengthening core relations among environmental values, beliefs, and norms. The sample consisted of students (n = 623) from 10 U.S. universities participating in a 4-week study abroad program to either Australia or New Zealand in 2008 and 2009. A pre-, posttest design was adopted in which students voluntarily completed a survey instrument on the first and last days of the program in the destination country. Results of the study suggested that the modified Value\u2013Belief\u2013Norm approach provides a robust theoretical framework, used in conjunction with theories of learning, for explaining how proenvironmental behavior is nurtured. These findings provided empirical support for the efficacy of short-term study abroad programs and developed further support for the importance of strong pedagogical techniques implemented by competent instructors.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Christopher J Wynveen&quot;,&quot;G.
