Poi traduttori lo e con la stessa moda e stylo di me quando noi abbiamo parlato in italiano. Pero, devi farlo con gramatica correta, farmi tanti fluenta, lo sai? \n\nHarnessing the Power of Intention Transforming Emotions and Shaping Our\u00a0Reality\nNavigating Life&#x27;s Rollercoaster\nLife often resembles a thrilling rollercoaster ride, filled with unexpected twists and turns that can leave us feeling exhilarated one moment and overwhelmed the next. Picture those mornings when it seems like the universe is playing tricks on us\u200a-\u200arushing out the door, only to miss our train and find ourselves stranded on a crowded platform, frustrated and frazzled by the chaos of everyday life. In these moments, it&#x27;s natural to question whether we can truly choose happiness amidst the whirlwind of life&#x27;s challenges.\nBut here&#x27;s the thing about rollercoasters\u200a-\u200awhile we can&#x27;t control the twists and turns of the track, we can control how we respond to the ride. Similarly, in the rollercoaster of life, we may not always have control over our external circumstances, but we have complete control over how we navigate and perceive them. It&#x27;s within this realm of control that the power of intention comes into play, offering us a pathway to cultivate happiness and peace.\nLet&#x27;s delve into the intriguing world of intention and how it affects our emotions and reality. We will consider some practical strategies based on scientific research and modern philosophy that can help us cope with life&#x27;s inevitable highs and lows.\nThe Science of Intention: Rewiring Our Brain for Positivity\nIn the realm of neuroscience, pioneering researchers like Haggard have uncovered fascinating insights into the power of intention. Haggard&#x27;s groundbreaking work suggests that our brains begin preparing for action before we&#x27;re even consciously aware of it, indicating that our intentions have a direct impact on our neural pathways (Haggard, 2005).\nOne practical way to leverage this insight is by starting our day with a clear intention or goal in mind. Setting a positive intention can help prime our brain for success and focus our energy on what matters most to us.\nPhilosophical Musings: Intentions vs. Willpower\nVenturing into the realm of philosophy, scholars such as Adams and Mele engage in thought-provoking debates surrounding intention and willpower. They propose that our actions are influenced not only by sheer will but also by the intricate interplay between intention, effort, and feedback (Adams &amp; Mele, 1992).\nTo cultivate a mindset of resilience, we can reframe challenges as opportunities for growth. Embracing a &quot;growth mindset&quot; enables us to approach difficulties with optimism and determination, aligning our intentions with our actions.\nEmbracing Intentionality: Finding Peace in the\u00a0Chaos\nRenowned philosopher Rollo May sheds light on the concept of intentionality as the cornerstone of human will. May&#x27;s insights urge us to realign our deeper intentions to reshape our perception of reality, even in the face of adversity (May, 1965).\nTo practice intentionality in our daily lives, we can incorporate mindfulness techniques. Staying present and fully engaged in the moment allows us to cultivate inner peace and acceptance, regardless of external circumstances.\nThe Role of Willpower: Strengthening Our Mental Resilience\nFurther studies by Fitch and Ravlin underscore the vital role of willpower in shaping our actions and emotional responses. Their findings suggest that nurturing strong willpower allows us to maintain inner calm and resilience, even amidst life&#x27;s most challenging moments (Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005).\nTo build our willpower &quot;muscle,&quot; we can set small, achievable goals and gradually increase the level of challenge. Celebrating our successes along the way reinforces positive behaviors and strengthens our resolve.\nEmpowering Ourselves Through Intention\nThe interplay between intention, willpower, and emotional experiences offers a profound perspective on navigating life&#x27;s rollercoaster. While we may not always have control over the twists and turns of the track, the power of intention empowers us to take control of our emotional responses and shape our reality from within.\nJust as a skilled rollercoaster rider anticipates each turn and loop with confidence and composure, we can also cultivate happiness and peace by aligning our intentions with our actions. By living with intentionality and mindfulness, we create a life that is meaningful and fulfilling, regardless of the external circumstances we encounter along the way.\nFurther Exploration: Diving Deeper into Intention and Its\u00a0Impact\nFor those intrigued by the dynamics of intention, willpower, and emotion, delving into the realms of cognitive neuroscience, philosophy of mind, and psychology, a significant article to consider is &quot;Conscious intention and motor cognition&quot; by P. Haggard (2005), published in Trends in Cognitive Sciences. This article provides a comprehensive view that bridges the gap between abstract philosophical discussions and tangible neuroscientific findings, offering a rich platform for exploring the power of human intention and willpower in shaping our emotional and behavioral responses.\nAs we continue on our journey of exploration, let&#x27;s remain curious and open-minded, experimenting with different techniques and approaches to see what resonates most with us and fits best into our lifestyle."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "85f65ceb4cff74e8-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aee58482-0237-4e12-9570-cb8af2b09fb3", "children": ["6aa40197-00de-4b2c-9a04-983c20a3af28"]}, "6aa40197-00de-4b2c-9a04-983c20a3af28": {"id": "6aa40197-00de-4b2c-9a04-983c20a3af28", "message": {"id": "6aa40197-00de-4b2c-9a04-983c20a3af28", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709602473.70144, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Sfruttare il Potere dell&#x27;Intenzione: Trasformare le Emozioni e Modellare la Nostra Realt\u00e0\n\nNavigare sulle Montagne Russe della Vita\nLa vita spesso somiglia a un&#x27;entusiasmante corsa sulle montagne russe, piena di inaspettati tornanti e svolte che possono lasciarci estasiati un momento e sopraffatti il successivo. Immaginate quelle mattine in cui sembra che l&#x27;universo ci stia giocando brutti scherzi: uscire di corsa dalla porta solo per perdere il treno e trovarsi bloccati su un marciapiede affollato, frustrati e stressati dal caos della vita quotidiana. In questi momenti, \u00e8 naturale chiedersi se possiamo davvero scegliere la felicit\u00e0 in mezzo al turbine delle sfide della vita.\nMa ecco la cosa sulle montagne russe: mentre non possiamo controllare i tornanti e le svolte del percorso, possiamo controllare come reagiamo al viaggio. Allo stesso modo, nella montagna russa della vita, potremmo non sempre avere il controllo sulle nostre circostanze esterne, ma abbiamo il completo controllo su come le navighiamo e le percepiamo. \u00c8 proprio in questo ambito di controllo che il potere dell&#x27;intenzione entra in gioco, offrendoci un percorso per coltivare felicit\u00e0 e pace.\nApprofondiamo il mondo intrigante dell&#x27;intenzione e come essa influisce sulle nostre emozioni e sulla realt\u00e0. Esamineremo alcune strategie pratiche basate sulla ricerca scientifica e sulla filosofia moderna che possono aiutarci a far fronte agli alti e bassi inevitabili della vita.\nLa Scienza dell&#x27;Intenzione: Riscrivere il Nostro Cervello per la Positivit\u00e0\nNell&#x27;ambito delle neuroscienze, ricercatori pionieristici come Haggard hanno scoperto insight affascinanti sul potere dell&#x27;intenzione. Il lavoro innovativo di Haggard suggerisce che i nostri cervelli iniziano a prepararsi per l&#x27;azione prima che ne siamo consapevoli, indicando che le nostre intenzioni hanno un impatto diretto sulle nostre vie neurali (Haggard, 2005).\nUn modo pratico per sfruttare questo insight \u00e8 iniziare la nostra giornata con un&#x27;intenzione o un obiettivo chiaro in mente. Stabilire un&#x27;intenzione positiva pu\u00f2 aiutare a predisporre il nostro cervello per il successo e concentrare la nostra energia su ci\u00f2 che per noi conta di pi\u00f9.\nRiflessioni Filosofiche: Intenzioni vs. Forza di Volont\u00e0\nAddentrandoci nel campo della filosofia, studiosi come Adams e Mele si impegnano in dibattiti stimolanti su intenzione e forza di volont\u00e0. Essi propongono che le nostre azioni siano influenzate non solo dalla pura volont\u00e0, ma anche dall&#x27;interazione intricata tra intenzione, sforzo e feedback (Adams &amp; Mele, 1992).\nPer coltivare una mentalit\u00e0 di resilienza, possiamo riformulare le sfide come opportunit\u00e0 di crescita. Abbracciando una &quot;mentalit\u00e0 di crescita&quot;, possiamo affrontare le difficolt\u00e0 con ottimismo e determinazione, allineando le nostre intenzioni con le nostre azioni.\nAbbracciare l&#x27;Intenzionalit\u00e0: Trovare Pace nel Caos\nIl rinomato filosofo Rollo May fa luce sul concetto di intenzionalit\u00e0 come pietra angolare della volont\u00e0 umana. Le intuizioni di May ci spingono a riallineare le nostre intenzioni pi\u00f9 profonde per plasmare la nostra percezione della realt\u00e0, anche di fronte all&#x27;avversit\u00e0 (May, 1965).\nPer praticare l&#x27;intenzionalit\u00e0 nella nostra vita quotidiana, possiamo incorporare tecniche di mindfulness. Rimanere presenti e completamente impegnati nel momento ci consente di coltivare pace interiore e accettazione, indipendentemente dalle circostanze esterne.\nIl Ruolo della Forza di Volont\u00e0: Rafforzare la Nostra Resilienza Mentale\nUlteriori studi condotti da Fitch e Ravlin sottolineano il ruolo vitale della forza di volont\u00e0 nel plasmare le nostre azioni e le nostre risposte emotive. Rollercoaster\nLife often resembles a thrilling rollercoaster ride, filled with unexpected twists and turns that can leave us feeling exhilarated one moment and overwhelmed the next. Picture those mornings when it seems like the universe is playing tricks on us \u2014 rushing out the door, only to miss our train and find ourselves stranded on a crowded platform, frustrated and frazzled by the chaos of everyday life. In these moments, it\u2019s natural to question whether we can truly choose happiness amidst the whirlwind of life\u2019s challenges.\n\nBut here\u2019s the thing about rollercoasters \u2014 while we can\u2019t control the twists and turns of the track, we can control how we respond to the ride. Similarly, in the rollercoaster of life, we may not always have control over our external circumstances, but we have complete control over how we navigate and perceive them. It\u2019s within this realm of control that the power of intention comes into play, offering us a pathway to cultivate happiness and peace.\n\nLet&#x27;s delve into the intriguing world of intention and how it affects our emotions and reality. We will consider some practical strategies based on scientific research and modern philosophy that can help us cope with life&#x27;s inevitable highs and lows.\n\nThe Science of Intention: Rewiring Our Brain for Positivity\nIn the realm of neuroscience, pioneering researchers like Haggard have uncovered fascinating insights into the power of intention. Haggard\u2019s groundbreaking work suggests that our brains begin preparing for action before we\u2019re even consciously aware of it, indicating that our intentions have a direct impact on our neural pathways (Haggard, 2005).\n\nOne practical way to leverage this insight is by starting our day with a clear intention or goal in mind. Setting a positive intention can help prime our brain for success and focus our energy on what matters most to us.\n\nPhilosophical Musings: Intentions vs. Willpower\nVenturing into the realm of philosophy, scholars such as Adams and Mele engage in thought-provoking debates surrounding intention and willpower. They propose that our actions are influenced not only by sheer will but also by the intricate interplay between intention, effort, and feedback (Adams &amp; Mele, 1992).\n\nTo cultivate a mindset of resilience, we can reframe challenges as opportunities for growth. Embracing a \u201cgrowth mindset\u201d enables us to approach difficulties with optimism and determination, aligning our intentions with our actions.\n\nEmbracing Intentionality: Finding Peace in the Chaos\nRenowned philosopher Rollo May sheds light on the concept of intentionality as the cornerstone of human will. May\u2019s insights urge us to realign our deeper intentions to reshape our perception of reality, even in the face of adversity (May, 1965).\n\nTo practice intentionality in our daily lives, we can incorporate mindfulness techniques. Staying present and fully engaged in the moment allows us to cultivate inner peace and acceptance, regardless of external circumstances.\n\nThe Role of Willpower: Strengthening Our Mental Resilience\nFurther studies by Fitch and Ravlin underscore the vital role of willpower in shaping our actions and emotional responses. Their findings suggest that nurturing strong willpower allows us to maintain inner calm and resilience, even amidst life\u2019s most challenging moments (Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005).\n\nTo build our willpower \u201cmuscle,\u201d we can set small, achievable goals and gradually increase the level of challenge. Celebrating our successes along the way reinforces positive behaviors and strengthens our resolve.\n\nEmpowering Ourselves Through Intention\nThe interplay between intention, willpower, and emotional experiences offers a profound perspective on navigating life\u2019s rollercoaster. While we may not always have control over the twists and turns of the track, the power of intention empowers us to take control of our emotional responses and shape our reality from within.\n\nJust as a skilled rollercoaster rider anticipates each turn and loop with confidence and composure, we can also cultivate happiness and peace by aligning our intentions with our actions. By living with intentionality and mindfulness, we create a life that is meaningful and fulfilling, regardless of the external circumstances we encounter along the way.\n\nFurther Exploration: Diving Deeper into Intention and Its Impact\nFor those intrigued by the dynamics of intention, willpower, and emotion, delving into the realms of cognitive neuroscience, philosophy of mind, and psychology, a significant article to consider is \u201cConscious intention and motor cognition\u201d by P. Haggard (2005), published in Trends in Cognitive Sciences. This article provides a comprehensive view that bridges the gap between abstract philosophical discussions and tangible neuroscientific findings, offering a rich platform for exploring the power of human intention and willpower in shaping our emotional and behavioral responses.\n\nAs we continue on our journey of exploration, let\u2019s remain curious and open-minded, experimenting with different techniques and approaches to see what resonates most with us and fits best into our lifestyle."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "85f63fd15fe2a259-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4e503323-64a5-4327-b2d0-9a9070ba9a02", "children": ["17de71e4-09ec-40eb-a4bb-2408566bad77"]}, "17de71e4-09ec-40eb-a4bb-2408566bad77": {"id": "17de71e4-09ec-40eb-a4bb-2408566bad77", "message": {"id": "17de71e4-09ec-40eb-a4bb-2408566bad77", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709601278.858752, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["For the article &quot;Harnessing the Power of Intention: Transforming Emotions and Shaping Our Reality&quot; Intention&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The paper argues that while the state of mind of an agent exercising power is relevant in analyzing the concept of power, much of the discussion about whether an intention must be complied with for there to be an exercise of power misconceives the issue at stake because it overrates the extent to which human behavior is ratiocinative. The argument is developed in the course of a discussion of several hypothetical examples. One conclusion is that for a person to exercise power it is normally necessary that he should have a favorable attitude to the effects in question, the word \u201cfavorable\u201d being used because it is highly general and hence relatively non-restrictive. Philosophers studying &#x27;conscious free will&#x27; have discussed whether conscious intentions could cause actions, but modern neuroscience rejects this idea of mind-body causation. Instead, recent findings suggest that the conscious experience of intending to act arises from preparation for action in frontal and parietal brain areas. Intentional actions also involve a strong sense of agency, a sense of controlling events in the external world. Both intention and agency result from the brain processes for predictive motor control, not merely from retrospective inference.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Haggard&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Trends in Cognitive Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.tics.2005.04.012&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;9&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;290-295&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Intention/Volition Debate1&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;People intend to do things, try to do things, and do things. Do they also will to do things? More precisely, if people will to do things and their willing bears upon what they do, is willing, or volition, something distinct from intending and trying? This question is central to the intention/volition debate, a debate about the ingredients of the best theory of the nature and explanation of human action. A variety of competing conceptions of volition, intention, and trying have been advanced in the literature; it would be impossible to examine each thoroughly in a single paper. We can show, however, that the major functional roles ascribed to volition are nicely filled by a triad composed of intention, trying, and information feedback. Sections I and II below develop an account of the connection between intention and trying. Section III examines leading arguments for the existence of volitions and decomposes volitions into members of the triad just identified.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Adams&quot;,&quot;A. Mele&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1992,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Canadian Journal of Philosophy&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/00455091.1992.10717283&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;22&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;323 - 337&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intentionality, the Heart of Human Will&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;THE concept of intentionality was central in the philosophy and psychology of the Middle Ages, but was perforce thrown out by Descartes&#x27; dichotomy between body and mind. For intentionality is the bridge that makes just such a bifurcation impossible. The concept was then reintroduced by Franz Brentano in the last half of the nineteenth century, whose forceful lectures at the University of Vienna both Freud and Husserl attended. Intentionality is present in all psychotherapy, and is shown in significant ways in Freud. But the concept has been almost entirely left out of our academic psychology, much to the impoverishment, I believe, of our understanding not only of human experience in the area of wish and will but of consciousness as well. Intentionality is at the heart of consciousness. I believe it is likewise the key to the problem of wish and will. Some readers might immediately identify intentionality with mere voluntarism and purposivism, and conclude prematurely that what I am discussing is only the obvious fact that we look at things with different goals in mind. But something considerably more significant than that is going on. To take an illustration from therapy: a patient&#x27;s voluntary intention, so far as he is consciously aware of it, is to get to his hour on time, to tell me this or that important thing that has happened to him, to relax and free associate. But his intentionality, in contrast, may well be to please me by playing the role of the \\&quot;good patient,\\&quot; or to impress me with how brilliant his free associations are, or to force my unconditioned attention by describing what catastrophic things he may do to himself or others. Intention is a conscious, psychological state; I can set myself voluntarily to do this or that. Intentionality, rather, refers to a state of being, and involves to a greater or lesser degree the totality of the person&#x27;s orientation to the world at that time. This may be opposite to conscious intention. And what is most interesting is the times in psychotherapy when strong voluntary intentioncorrelated with \\&quot;will power\\&quot; gets in the way of the person&#x27;s intentionality, and is just what blocks communicating with the deeper dimensions of his experience.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. May&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1965,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Humanistic Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/002216786500500209&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;5&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;202 - 209&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Action as Will-Power&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The concept of power, as commonly formulated in contemporary sociology, is noted to lack any reference to the critical dimension of personal conative striving, or will-power. This deficiency is shown to stem from an overly cognitive conception of action, one in which acts are seen to embody choice and meaning but not emotion or effort, a view that has been reinforced by the use of trivial, easily-accomplished acts as examples to illustrate the nature of action. A perspective is advocated that redresses this imbalance; one that accepts that the immediate cause of all true actions is an act of will and that action is best conceived of as behaviour that individuals allow to happen to them. Power is then defined as an individual&#x27;s ability to initiate and maintain action despite behavioural resistance, a conceptualization that closely links it to the concept of \u2018character\u2019. This perspective on human conduct is then shown to be identical to that adopted by Weber in The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Campbell&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1999,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The Sociological Review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/action-willpower-campbell/76463d032d5e504bb29c07e24116665e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/1467-954X.00162&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;47&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;48 - 61&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Willpower and perceived behavioral control: Influences on the intention-behavior relationship and postbehavior attributions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Individual differences in willpower (a subdimension of conscientiousness) and perceived behavioral control (PBC: cognition regarding extent of control over an action; Ajzen, 1985) in the intention-behavior relationship were explored to better understand when intention will be completed to action. The impact of these constructs in postbehavior attributions also was explored. Participants were traditional and nontraditional students (N = 325) preparing for examinations at two time periods. Rather than confirming main effects proposed by prior research (e.g., Ajzen), moderation effects characterized these data. At Time 1, individuals higher in willpower behaved more consistently with their intentions. At Time 2, individuals higher in PBC showed a similar effect. Lower willpower also led subjects to make less attribution to effort when expectations were exceeded.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Judy L. Fitch&quot;,&quot;Elizabeth C. Ravlin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social Behavior and Personality&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2224/SBP.2005.33.2.105&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;33&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;105-124&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;INTENTION, AUTHENTICITY AND ESSENCE: The Challenge of Evocation&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Through the power of intention we manifest our human desires and our spiritual aspirations. As we look about we must question both the source and the outcome of the intentions behind the reality we now experience on this planet. Human intentions arise from within the personality or are, at very least, greatly influenced by the personality. Integral, unambiguous, and beneficent intentions can only emerge from an integral and unambiguous personality. Perhaps our greatest human challenge is the transformational journey towards authentic pesonal integrity. This presidential address explores both personal and spiritual aspects of that journey.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Nunley&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Subtle Energies &amp; Energy Medicine Journal Archives&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-authenticity-essence-challenge-evocation-nunley/b42bafd5bdd551d4ad8497d8e72e894e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;9&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Towards computational models of intention detection and intention prediction&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intention recognition is one of the core components of mindreading, an important process in social cognition. Human beings, from age of 18months, have been shown to be able to extrapolate intentions from observed actions, even when the performer failed at achieving the goal. Existing accounts of intention recognition emphasize the use of an intent (plan) library, which is matched against observed actions for recognition. These therefore cannot account for recognition of failed sequences of actions, nor novel actions. In this paper, we begin to tackle these open questions by examining computational models for components of human intention recognition, which emphasize the ability of humans to detect and identify intentions in a sequence of observed actions, based solely on the rationality of movement (its efficiency). We provide a high-level overview of intention recognition as a whole, and then elaborate on two components of the model, which we believe to be at its core, namely, those of intention detection and intention prediction. By intention detection we mean the ability to discern whether a sequence of actions has any underlying intention at all, or whether it was performed in an arbitrary manner with no goal in mind. By intention prediction we mean the ability to extend an incomplete sequence of actions to its most likely intended goal. We evaluate the model, and these two components, in context of existing literature, and in a number of experiments with more than 140 human subjects. For intention detection, our model was able to attribute high levels of intention to those traces perceived by humans as intentional, and vice versa. For intention prediction as well, our model performed in a way that closely matched that of humans. The work highlights the intimate relationship between the ability to generate plans, and the ability to recognize intentions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Elisheva Bonchek-Dokow&quot;,&quot;G. Kaminka&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognitive Systems Research&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/towards-models-intention-detection-intention-prediction-bonchekdokow/12fb4f629bde5512907e1e203006b49f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.cogsys.2013.07.004&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;28&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;44-79&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Power and Choice&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Power and choice represent two fundamental forces that govern human behavior. Scholars have largely treated power as an interpersonal construct involving control over other individuals, whereas choice has largely been treated as an intrapersonal construct that concerns the ability to select a preferred course of action. Although these constructs have historically been studied separately, we propose that they share a common foundation\u2014that both are rooted in an individual\u2019s sense of personal control. Because of this common underlying basis, we hypothesized that power and choice are substitutable; that is, we predicted that the absence of one would increase the desire for the other, which, when acquired, would serve to satisfy the broader need for control. We also predicted that choice and power would exhibit a threshold effect, such that once one source of control had been provided (e.g., power), the addition of the other (e.g., choice) would yield diminishing returns. Six experiments provide evidence supporting these predictions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;D. Dubois&quot;,&quot;Ena Inesi&quot;,&quot;Simona Botti&quot;,&quot;Derek D. Rucker&quot;,&quot;A. Galinsky&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychological Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/power-choice-dubois/c7f899e4b6035b948d24e06fd9b7ff9a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0956797611413936&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;22&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1042 - 1048&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;[Evidence about the power of intention].&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intention is defined as a directed thought to perform a determined action. Thoughts targeted to an end can affect inanimate objects and practically all living things from unicelular organisms to human beings. The emission of light particles (biophotons) seems to be the mechanism through which an intention produces its effects. All living organisms emit a constant current of photons as a mean to direct instantaneous nonlocal signals from one part of the body to another and to the outside world. Biophotons are stored in the intracelular DNA. When the organism is sick changes in biophotons emissions are produced.Direct intention manifests itself as an electric and magnetic energy producing an ordered flux of photons. Our intentions seem to operate as highly coherent frequencies capable of changing the molecular structure of matter. For the intention to be effective it is necessary to choose the appropriate time. In fact, living beings are mutually synchronized and to the earth and its constant changes of magnetic energy. It has been shown that the energy of thought can also alter the environment. Hypnosis, stigmata phenomena and the placebo effect can also be considered as types of intention, as instructions to the brain during a particular state of consciousness. Cases of spontaneous cures or of remote healing of extremely ill patients represent instances of an exceedingly great intention to control diseases menacing our lives. The intention to heal as well as the beliefs of the sick person on the efficacy of the healing influences promote his healing. In conclusion, studies on thought and consciousness are emerging as fundamental aspects and not as mere epiphenomena that are rapidly leading to a profound change in the paradigms of Biology and Medicine.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. However, it has remained unclear whether this prefrontal activity encodes a subject&#x27;s current intention. Instead, increased levels of activity could reflect preparation of motor responses, holding in mind a set of potential choices, tracking the memory of previous responses, or general processes related to establishing a new task set. Here we study subjects who freely decided which of two tasks to perform and covertly held onto an intention during a variable delay. Only after this delay did they perform the chosen task and indicate which task they had prepared. We demonstrate that during the delay, it is possible to decode from activity in medial and lateral regions of prefrontal cortex which of two tasks the subjects were covertly intending to perform. This suggests that covert goals can be represented by distributed patterns of activity in the prefrontal cortex, thereby providing a potential neural substrate for prospective memory. During task execution, most information could be decoded from a more posterior region of prefrontal cortex, suggesting that different brain regions encode goals during task preparation and task execution. Decoding of intentions was most robust from the medial prefrontal cortex, which is consistent with a specific role of this region when subjects reflect on their own mental states.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. The unique feature of the proposed function lies in the fact that it utilizes multi-communication channels in parallel. i.e., human intentions are understood not only through conscious behavior but also through unconscious behavior. The paper also proposes a robot architecture to realize the function. The following points are the key features of the architecture: a robot possesses multi-sensors which surround the human; and information processing is carried out by dual loops-a loop for information exchange between the human and the robot and a loop for human intention understanding. It can automatically understand an operator&#x27;s intention through such unconscious behavior of touching a desk with an operator&#x27;s hand. "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709587371.473827, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Certainly, let&#x27;s delve deeper into the studies cited in points 4 through 6 for a more comprehensive overview:\n\n### 4. Conscious Intention and Motor Cognition [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nIn this study, the author explores the subjective experience of conscious intention, which is a key component of our mental life. Philosophical discussions have questioned whether conscious intentions can cause actions. Modern neuroscience, however, shifts this debate by suggesting that the experience of intending to act originates from action preparation processes in frontal and parietal brain areas. This study highlights that both the sense of intention and the sense of agency\u2014our feeling of controlling events in the external world\u2014are results of the brain&#x27;s mechanisms for predictive motor control rather than merely retrospective inferences. This insight reshapes our understanding of conscious free will by grounding it in specific brain processes rather than abstract philosophical concepts.\n\n### 5. The Intention/Volition Debate [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nThis paper delves into the ongoing debate regarding the nature and existence of volition and how it relates to intention and the process of trying. The authors argue that the major roles traditionally ascribed to the concept of volition can be effectively fulfilled by a combination of intention, the act of trying, and feedback mechanisms. This suggests a more integrated approach to understanding human action, where intention and the effort of trying, combined with the response to feedback, play crucial roles. The study challenges the need for a distinct concept of volition beyond these elements, proposing a simplified framework for analyzing human behavior.\n\n### 6. Intentionality, the Heart of Human Will [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt)\nRollo May&#x27;s work revives the medieval concept of intentionality, which was sidelined by the Cartesian mind-body dichotomy. Intentionality is described as the bridge between mind and body, making their bifurcation impossible. May argues that intentionality is central to understanding human consciousness and the dynamics of wish and will. Unlike mere conscious intentions or desires, intentionality encompasses a broader state of being, reflecting the individual&#x27;s total orientation to the world at any given time. This can include unconscious drives and motivations, revealing a more complex interplay between an individual&#x27;s conscious goals and their underlying intentionality. May emphasizes that understanding this concept is crucial for psychotherapy and offers a richer understanding of human experience, beyond the limitations of traditional academic psychology.\n\nEach of these studies offers a unique perspective on the nature of human intention and will, from the neurological underpinnings to philosophical debates and psychological interpretations, contributing to a comprehensive understanding of these complex phenomena."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": "43b29490-12bf-4c4c-be98-74ea6f8f277b", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709587527.040278, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Sure, here&#x27;s a more comprehensive overview of the studies cited in points 4 through 7:\n\n4. **Conscious intention and motor cognition** [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt): This paper discusses the neuroscientific perspective on conscious intention and action. It challenges the classical notion of conscious intentions causing actions, suggesting instead that the feeling of intention results from brain activity preparing for action. The study indicates that both intention and the sense of agency (feeling in control of actions) stem from the brain&#x27;s predictive mechanisms for motor control, rather than from a post-action rationalization process. This perspective shifts the understanding of free will and conscious decision-making by proposing a model where conscious intention arises as a byproduct of the brain&#x27;s motor preparation processes.\n\n5. **The Intention/Volition Debate1** [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt): Adams and Mele explore the distinctions between intention, volition, and trying in human action. They scrutinize the philosophical and psychological aspects of human action, questioning whether there is a need to distinguish between willing to do things and merely intending or trying to do them. The authors propose that the functions usually attributed to volition can be explained by a combination of intention, trying, and feedback from actions, arguing that these elements sufficiently account for human action without needing to invoke an additional concept of volition. This paper contributes to the philosophical debate on the nature of human action and the mechanisms underlying intentional behavior.\n\n6. **Intentionality, the Heart of Human Will** [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt): Rollo May&#x27;s work delves into the concept of intentionality as fundamental to human consciousness and action, arguing against the Cartesian dualism of mind and body. May emphasizes that intentionality is a bridging concept that renders such a dualism untenable. He discusses how intentionality is crucial in psychotherapy and human experience, impacting areas of wish, will, and consciousness. By examining the discrepancy between a person&#x27;s conscious intentions and their deeper, often unconscious, intentionality, May illustrates how understanding this concept can lead to a richer understanding of human behavior and psychotherapeutic processes.\n\n7. **Willpower and perceived behavioral control: Influences on the intention-behavior relationship and postbehavior attributions** [(Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt): This study examines how individual differences in willpower (related to conscientiousness) and perceived behavioral control (the belief about how much control one has over their actions) affect the relationship between intentions and behaviors. The authors investigate how these factors influence whether a person&#x27;s intentions lead to actual behaviors and how people attribute causes to their behaviors post-action. Their findings suggest that willpower and perceived behavioral control can moderate the strength of the intention-behavior link and influence how individuals attribute success or failure, which has significant implications for understanding motivation and self-regulation.\n\nThese studies collectively provide insights into the cognitive and neurological underpinnings of human intention and willpower, offering a multifaceted understanding of how intentions guide behavior and how our brain constructs the sense of agency and decision-making."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "parent_id": "aaa213fb-aaf7-4cf8-b0f1-1183c70ab853", "request_id": "85f4ef3a8e9ca262-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa213fb-aaf7-4cf8-b0f1-1183c70ab853", "children": ["aaa215c7-c658-41d0-a331-d4bcf67b528e"]}, "aaa215c7-c658-41d0-a331-d4bcf67b528e": {"id": "aaa215c7-c658-41d0-a331-d4bcf67b528e", "message": {"id": "aaa215c7-c658-41d0-a331-d4bcf67b528e", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709588110.954971, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Cite and use information, quotes and details from the papers above to create a comprehensive blog post using the text below as a starting point.  Discuss the findings of science that support the ideas purported in the text below also discussing any philosophical underpinnings and psychological schools of thought that may go hand in hand will the central idea that if you decide to be happy, you&#x27;ll be happy, the power of intention, and the idea that we control our emotions. Add any supplemental references that may further these points. \n\nPicture this: You rush determinately out of your home towards the public transport. You make it to the platform just in time to see your train go by, leaving the station without you. Now you must wait on the platform, crowded with many others, feeling hot, sweaty, perhaps a bit miserable, thinking of going to a job that you don&#x27;t care for, with people you don&#x27;t like, for pay you consider a pittance just to pay your bills. And as you stand dispassionately on that train platform, you look around at people who likely feel the same. This is the reality.\n\nYou feel empty, anxious, sad, anticipatory, helpless, hopeless, all of the negative, dark, hollow, sunken place emotions all at once. Perhaps you feel none of them, or maybe you just feel just one. Perhaps you question the point of this moment. Perhaps you don&#x27;t understand how you feel. But in this moment, could you believe that it&#x27;s entirely up to you? Could you believe that you have complete control over how you experience this situation? Could you believe that your emotions are all in your hands?\n\nStudies show that the power of human intention, of human will, defies known science. There have been occasions where merely someone&#x27;s will and decision that they could not do something made it so that they could not do that thing. The power of intention, the power of human will, is beyond so much of what we understand right now. If you decide that you&#x27;re happy, then you&#x27;re happy. If you intend to maintain a sense of inner peace, that is what will happen. What you expect generally occurs sometimes. We&#x27;re surprised, but what we focus on the most is what we bring about."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "85f4fe9b9c3ea259-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "43b29490-12bf-4c4c-be98-74ea6f8f277b", "children": ["94a65371-2a01-4804-bded-aff6eba7da24"]}, "94a65371-2a01-4804-bded-aff6eba7da24": {"id": "94a65371-2a01-4804-bded-aff6eba7da24", "message": {"id": "94a65371-2a01-4804-bded-aff6eba7da24", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709588155.30998, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["**Harnessing the Power of Intention: Transforming Emotions and Shaping Our Reality**\n\nImagine a typical morning scenario: rushing out of the house, missing your train, and finding yourself stranded on a crowded platform. Amid the chaos, discomfort, and dissatisfaction with your job, you&#x27;re overwhelmed with negative emotions. In this all-too-familiar setting, it&#x27;s hard to believe that happiness could be a matter of personal choice. Yet, emerging scientific research and philosophical debates suggest that our intentions and willpower significantly shape our emotional experiences and realities.\n\nThe concept of conscious intention and its role in our actions has been scrutinized by researchers like Haggard (2005), who explored how our brain prepares for action and how this relates to our subjective experience of intention. Contrary to the traditional belief in free will, Haggard&#x27;s findings suggest that the feeling of intending to act arises from the brain&#x27;s preparation for action, highlighting the predictive nature of motor control mechanisms. This scientific perspective challenges the notion of direct mind-body causation but supports the idea that by focusing our intention, we may harness the brain&#x27;s predictive capacities to influence our emotional states [(Haggard, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nPhilosophically, the debate around intention and volition delves deeper into human agency. Adams and Mele (1992) discuss how intentions, combined with efforts and feedback, fulfill the roles ascribed to volition, suggesting that our actions are more a result of a complex interplay between intention and trying rather than sheer willpower alone. This aligns with the notion that deciding to adopt a positive outlook could indeed reshape one&#x27;s emotional landscape [(Adams &amp; Mele, 1992)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionvolition-debate1-adams/5bd4a67f0a4a56afb45781648f62a7f9/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nRollo May (1965) further illuminates the power of intentionality, arguing that it is at the heart of consciousness and human will. Intentionality, as a state of being, encompasses our total orientation towards the world at any given time, which could be contrary to our conscious intentions. This suggests that by realigning our deeper intentionality, we could transform our experience of reality, transcending the immediate negativity of a moment like missing a train [(May, 1965)](https://consensus.app/papers/intentionality-heart-human-will-may/359696f4be6e5b72a375f17be118d00e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nFurthermore, Fitch and Ravlin (2005) explore how willpower and perceived behavioral control influence our actions and emotional responses. Their research indicates that higher willpower correlates with behavior more consistent with one&#x27;s intentions. This supports the idea that strengthening our willpower and controlling our focus could enable us to maintain a sense of inner peace amidst chaos [(Fitch &amp; Ravlin, 2005)](https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nWhat these studies collectively suggest is that while our immediate circumstances might prompt automatic negative reactions, the broader capacity of our intentions\u2014shaped by complex neurological processes, philosophical understandings, and psychological efforts\u2014can significantly influence our emotional state. The scenario on the train platform, rather than being a moment of despair, can become an opportunity for practicing this power of intention. By deciding to view the situation differently, by intentionally shifting focus from the external to an inner sense of peace, we can control our emotions and, consequently, our happiness.\n\nIn conclusion, while external situations inevitably impact our emotions, the scientific and philosophical underpinnings of intention and willpower offer empowering perspectives. They suggest that by cultivating strong intentions and focusing our will, we can transform our emotional experiences and shape our reality. In the crowded train platform of life, it turns out, happiness could indeed be a choice \u2013 a choice rooted in the power of our intentions.\n\nFor those intrigued by the interplay between intention, willpower, and emotion, further exploration into the realms of cognitive neuroscience, philosophy of mind, and psychology may provide additional insights and practical strategies for harnessing this transformative power."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Conscious intention and motor cognition&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The subjective experience of conscious intention is a key component of our mental life. Philosophers studying &#x27;conscious free will&#x27; have discussed whether conscious intentions could cause actions, but modern neuroscience rejects this idea of mind-body causation. Instead, recent findings suggest that the conscious experience of intending to act arises from preparation for action in frontal and parietal brain areas. Intentional actions also involve a strong sense of agency, a sense of controlling events in the external world. Both intention and agency result from the brain processes for predictive motor control, not merely from retrospective inference.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Haggard&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Trends in Cognitive Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-motor-cognition-haggard/17b609fc3d54561e8cd455f937a543c6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.tics.2005.04.012&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;9&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;290-295&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Conscious intention and brain activity.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The problem of free will lies at the heart of modern scientific studies of consciousness. An influential series of experiments by Libet has suggested that conscious intentions arise as a result of brain activity. This contrasts with traditional concepts of free will, in which the mind controls the body. A more recent study by Haggard and Eimer has further examined the relation between intention and brain processes, concluding that conscious awareness of intention is linked to the choice or selection of a specific action, and not to the earliest initiation of action processes. The exchange of views in this paper further explores the relation between conscious intention and brain activity.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Haggard&quot;,&quot;B. Libet&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2001,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Consciousness Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/intention-brain-activity-haggard/1c74027863395287878ef3d7a5057ef7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Functional imaging of \u2018theory of mind\u2019&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Our ability to explain and predict other people&#x27;s behaviour by attributing to them independent mental states, such as beliefs and desires, is known as having a &#x27;theory of mind&#x27;. Interest in this very human ability has engendered a growing body of evidence concerning its evolution and development and the biological basis of the mechanisms underpinning it. Functional imaging has played a key role in seeking to isolate brain regions specific to this ability. Three areas are consistently activated in association with theory of mind. These are the anterior paracingulate cortex, the superior temporal sulci and the temporal poles bilaterally. This review discusses the functional significance of each of these areas within a social cognitive network.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;H. Gallagher&quot;,&quot;C. Frith&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Trends in Cognitive Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/imaging-theory-mind-gallagher/4474a7c036e9560a975365d35c8ea6c0/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/S1364-6613(02)00025-6&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;77-83&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intentional Minds: A Philosophical Analysis of Intention Tested through fMRI Experiments Involving People with Schizophrenia, People with Autism, and Healthy Individuals&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this paper we show how we empirically tested one of the most relevant topics in philosophy of mind through a series of fMRI experiments: the classification of different types of intention. To this aim, firstly we trace a theoretical distinction among private, prospective, and communicative intentions. Second, we propose a set of predictions concerning the recognition of these three types of intention in healthy individuals, and we report the experimental results corroborating our theoretical model of intention. Third, we derive from our model predictions relevant for the domain of psychopathological functioning. In particular, we treat the cases of both hyper-intentionality (as in paranoid schizophrenia) and hypo-intentionality (as in autistic spectrum disorders). Our conclusion is that the theoretical model of intention we propose contributes to enlarge our knowledge on the neurobiological bases of intention processing, in both healthy people and in people with impairments to the neurocognitive system that underlies intention recognition.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Bara&quot;,&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;H. Walter&quot;,&quot;M. Adenzato&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Frontiers in Human Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/minds-philosophical-analysis-intention-tested-fmri-bara/b729cec08e4156ebb5a693e7a7617c6b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3389/fnhum.2011.00007&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;5&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Frontal Lobe Contributions to Theory of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of mind, the ability to make inferences about others&#x27; mental states, seems to be a modular cognitive capacity that underlies humans&#x27; ability to engage in complex social interaction. It develops in several distinct stages, which can be measured with social reasoning tests of increasing difficulty. Individuals with Asperger&#x27;s syndrome, a mild form of autism, perform well on simpler theory of mind tests but show deficits on more developmentally advanced theory of mind tests. We tested patients with bilateral damage to orbito-frontal cortex (n = 5) and unilateral damage in left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (n = 5) on a series of theory of mind tasks varying in difficulty. Bilateral orbito-frontal lesion patients performed similarly to individuals with Asperger&#x27;s syndrome, performing well on simpler tests and showing deficits on tasks requiring more subtle social reasoning, such as the ability to recognize a faux pas. In contrast, no specific theory of mind deficits were evident in the unilateral dorsolateral frontal lesion patients. The dorsolateral lesion patients had difficulty only on versions of the tasks that placed demands on working memory.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Valerie E. Stone&quot;,&quot;Simon Baron-Cohen&quot;,&quot;Robert T. Knight&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/frontal-lobe-contributions-theory-mind-stone/01d8d03396025aa4b2a1e61e6a47e4ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1162/089892998562942&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;640-656&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Lay theories of willpower&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Some people believe that willpower relies on a limited resource and that performing cognitive work (such as using self-control) results in mental fatigue. Others believe that willpower is nonlimited and that performing cognitive work instead prepares and energizes them for more. These differing lay theories of willpower determine whether or not one\u2019s self-control performance actually does decrease or increase after use, with only limited-willpower theorists showing a decrease (the ego depletion effect). Due to the self-control requirements of everyday life, willpower theories also predict outcomes across domains of academics, health, goal-progress, interpersonal relationships, and well-being. Generally, limited-willpower theorists\u2019 belief in their limited capacity results in poorer outcomes, particularly during times of high demand. By understanding how willpower theories form and function, interventions that encourage nonlimited willpower theories may be created to improve people\u2019s performance and well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Z. Francis&quot;,&quot;V. Job&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2018,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social and Personality Psychology Compass&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/theories-willpower-francis/073b6a02c5725b1c905dde069dee2f79/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/SPC3.12381&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;12&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Philosophy of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Philosophy of mind concerns questions about mental phenomena that empirical research alone can&#x27;t settle, such as the nature of mental states and which sorts of things can have them-only living things, or also machines? Settling them requires reflection on such phenomena as consciousness, rationality, and intentionality; the &#x27;explanatory gaps&#x27; that seem to exist between these; and underlying physical phenomena and the different strategies-dualist, eliminativist, physicalist, and functionalist-that have been proposed for dealing with them. Copyright \u00a9 2010 John Wiley &amp; Sons, Ltd. For further resources related to this article, please visit the WIREs website.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Berit Brogaard&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/philosophy-mind-brogaard/21d8edb78e84531a98892d73fad0c099/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1163/1877-5888_rpp_sim_124381&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The intentional network: How the brain reads varieties of intentions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Social neuroscience provides insights into the neural correlates of the human capacity to explain and predict other people&#x27;s intentions, a capacity that lies at the core of the Theory of Mind (ToM) mechanism. Results from neuroimaging research describe a widely distributed neural system underlying ToM, including the right and left temporo-parietal junctions (TPJ), the precuneus, and the medial prefrontal cortex (MPFC). Nevertheless, there is disagreement in the literature concerning the key region for the ToM network. Some authors point to the MPFC, others to the right TPJ. In the effort to make a contribution to the debate, we propose a model of a dynamic ToM network consisting of four regions. We also introduce a novel theoretical distinction among varieties of intention, which differ by the nature of an individual&#x27;s pursued goal (private or social) and by the social interaction&#x27;s temporal dimension (present or future). Our results confirm the crucial role of both the MPFC and the right TPJ, but show that these areas are differentially engaged depending on the nature of the intention involved. Whereas the right TPJ and the precuneus are necessary for processing all types of prior intentions, the left TPJ and the anterior paracingulate cortex are specifically involved in the understanding of social intention. More specifically, the left TPJ is activated only when a subset of social intentions are involved (communicative intentions). Taken together, these results demonstrate the progressive recruitment of the ToM network along the theoretical dimensions introduced in the present paper.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;A. Ciaramidaro&quot;,&quot;M. Adenzato&quot;,&quot;Ivan Enrici&quot;,&quot;S. Erk&quot;,&quot;Lorenzo Pia&quot;,&quot;Lorenzo Pia&quot;,&quot;B. Bara&quot;,&quot;Henrik Walter&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2007,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuropsychologia&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/network-brain-reads-varieties-intentions-ciaramidaro/ec017cc8e2675f9886c96108b6fb4b54/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neuropsychologia.2007.05.011&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;45&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;3105-3113&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A hot/cool-system analysis of delay of gratification: dynamics of willpower.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;A 2-system framework is proposed for understanding the processes that enable--and undermine--self-control or \\&quot;willpower\\&quot; as exemplified in the delay of gratification paradigm. A cool, cognitive \\&quot;know\\&quot; system and a hot, emotional \\&quot;go\\&quot; system are postulated. The cool system is cognitive, emotionally neutral, contemplative, flexible, integrated, coherent, spatiotemporal, slow, episodic, and strategic. It is the seat of self-regulation and self-control. The hot system is the basis of emotionality, fears as well as passions--impulsive and reflexive--initially controlled by innate releasing stimuli (and, thus, literally under \\&quot;stimulus control\\&quot;): it is fundamental for emotional (classical) conditioning and undermines efforts at self-control. The balance between the hot and cool systems is determined by stress, developmental level, and the individual&#x27;s self-regulatory dynamics. The interactions between these systems allow explanation of findings on willpower from 3 decades of research.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Metcalfe&quot;,&quot;W. Mischel&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1999,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychological review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/hotcoolsystem-analysis-delay-gratification-dynamics-metcalfe/12d45c32dea15aa1b6a39c82cf8e0112/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0033-295X.106.1.3&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;106 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          3-19\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Willpower and perceived behavioral control: Influences on the intention-behavior relationship and postbehavior attributions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Individual differences in willpower (a subdimension of conscientiousness) and perceived behavioral control (PBC: cognition regarding extent of control over an action; Ajzen, 1985) in the intention-behavior relationship were explored to better understand when intention will be completed to action. The impact of these constructs in postbehavior attributions also was explored. Participants were traditional and nontraditional students (N = 325) preparing for examinations at two time periods. Rather than confirming main effects proposed by prior research (e.g., Ajzen), moderation effects characterized these data. At Time 1, individuals higher in willpower behaved more consistently with their intentions. At Time 2, individuals higher in PBC showed a similar effect. Lower willpower also led subjects to make less attribution to effort when expectations were exceeded.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Judy L. Fitch&quot;,&quot;Elizabeth C. Ravlin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Social Behavior and Personality&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/willpower-perceived-control-influences-fitch/99d5941af38155b98d9f6fab0f9a2c52/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2224/SBP.2005.33.2.105&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;33&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;105-124&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;A novel task assessing intention and emotion attribution: Italian standardization and normative data of the Story-based Empathy Task&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Theory of Mind (ToM), the process by which an individual imputes mental states to himself and others, is presently considered as a multidimensional cognitive domain, with two main facets (i.e., cognitive and affective ToM) accounting, respectively, for the ability to understand others\u2019 intention (intention attribution-IA) and emotions (emotion attribution-EA). Despite the large amount of literature investigating the behavioural and neural bases of mentalizing abilities in neurological conditions, there is still a lack of validated neuropsychological tools specifically designed to assess such skills. Here, we report the normative data of the Story-Based Empathy Task (SET), a non-verbal test developed for the assessment of intention and emotion attribution in the neurodegenerative conditions characterized by the impairment of social\u2013emotional abilities. It is an easy-to-administer task including 18 stimuli, sub-grouped into two experimental conditions assessing, respectively, the ability to infer others\u2019 intentions (SET-IA) and emotions (SET-EA), compared to a control condition of causal inference (SET-CI). Normative data were collected in 136 Italian subjects pooled across subgroups homogenous for age (range 20\u201379\u00a0years), sex, and education (at least 5\u00a0years). The results show a detrimental effect of age and a beneficial effect of education on both the global score and each subscale, for which we provide correction grids. This new task could be a useful tool to investigate both affective and cognitive aspects of ToM in the course of disorders of socio-emotional behaviour, such as the fronto-temporal dementia spectrum.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Dodich&quot;,&quot;C. Cerami&quot;,&quot;N. Canessa&quot;,&quot;C. Crespi&quot;,&quot;S. Iannaccone&quot;,&quot;A. Marcone&quot;,&quot;S. Realmuto&quot;,&quot;G. Lettieri&quot;,&quot;D. Perani&quot;,&quot;S. Cappa&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neurological Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/task-assessing-intention-emotion-attribution-dodich/857d4ac6161858fcb81a2793964f046f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/s10072-015-2281-3&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;36&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1907-1912&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Healthcare professionals&#x27; intentions and behaviours: A systematic review of studies based on social cognitive theories&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;BackgroundThere is an important gap between the implications of clinical research evidence and the routine clinical practice of healthcare professionals. Because individual decisions are often central to adoption of a clinical-related behaviour, more information about the cognitive mechanisms underlying behaviours is needed to improve behaviour change interventions targeting healthcare professionals. The aim of this study was to systematically review the published scientific literature about factors influencing health professionals&#x27; behaviours based on social cognitive theories. These theories refer to theories where individual cognitions/thoughts are viewed as processes intervening between observable stimuli and responses in real world situations.MethodsWe searched psycINFO, MEDLINE, EMBASE, CIHNAL, Index to theses, PROQUEST dissertations and theses and Current Contents for articles published in English only. We included studies that aimed to predict healthcare professionals&#x27; intentions and behaviours with a clear specification of relying on a social cognitive theory. Information on percent of explained variance (R2) was used to compute the overall frequency-weighted mean R2 to evaluate the efficacy of prediction in several contexts and according to different methodological aspects. The cognitive factors most consistently associated with prediction of healthcare professionals&#x27; intention and behaviours were documented.ResultsSeventy eight studies met the inclusion criteria. Among these studies, 72 provided information on the determinants of intention and 16 prospective studies provided information on the determinants of behaviour. The theory most often used as reference was the Theory of Reasoned Action (TRA) or its extension the Theory of Planned Behaviour (TPB). An overall frequency-weighted mean R2 of 0.31 was observed for the prediction of behaviour; 0.59 for the prediction of intention. A number of moderators influenced the efficacy of prediction; frequency-weighted mean R2 varied from 0.001 to 0.58 for behaviour and 0.19 to 0.81 for intention.ConclusionOur results suggest that the TPB appears to be an appropriate theory to predict behaviour whereas other theories better capture the dynamic underlying intention. In addition, given the variations in efficacy of prediction, special care should be given to methodological issues, especially to better define the context of behaviour performance.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Yet, later development, including possible patterns of breakdown, has important implications for current debate concerning the modularity/domain-specificity of the cognitive and neurological systems underlying theory of mind. This article reports a first study of theory of mind in normal aging. The results suggest that although performance on tasks with nonmental content may decrease with age, performance on theory of mind tasks remains intact and may even improve over the later adult years. The implications of these findings for the cognitive processes underlying theory of mind are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Francesca Happ\u00e9&quot;,&quot;Ellen Winner&quot;,&quot;H. Brownell&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Developmental psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/getting-wisdom-theory-mind-happ\u00e9/09942a44d1ed519ea6fc68505327adc8/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0012-1649.34.2.358&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;34 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          358-62\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;For the law, neuroscience changes nothing and everything.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The rapidly growing field of cognitive neuroscience holds the promise of explaining the operations of the mind in terms of the physical operations of the brain. Some suggest that our emerging understanding of the physical causes of human (mis)behaviour will have a transformative effect on the law. Others argue that new neuroscience will provide only new details and that existing legal doctrine can accommodate whatever new information neuroscience will provide. We argue that neuroscience will probably have a transformative effect on the law, despite the fact that existing legal doctrine can, in principle, accommodate whatever neuroscience will tell us. New neuroscience will change the law, not by undermining its current assumptions, but by transforming people&#x27;s moral intuitions about free will and responsibility. This change in moral outlook will result not from the discovery of crucial new facts or clever new arguments, but from a new appreciation of old arguments, bolstered by vivid new illustrations provided by cognitive neuroscience. We foresee, and recommend, a shift away from punishment aimed at retribution in favour of a more progressive, consequentialist approach to the criminal law.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Joshua D. Greene&quot;,&quot;J. Cohen&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neuroscience-changes-nothing-everything-greene/c9239ad4a6695c57b1c4a9c51672e1be/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1098/RSTB.2004.1546&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;359 1451&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          1775-85\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Intention Concepts and Brain-Machine Interfacing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intentions, including their temporal properties and semantic content, are receiving increased attention, and neuroscientific studies in humans vary with respect to the topography of intention-related neural responses. This may reflect the fact that the kind of intentions investigated in one study may not be exactly the same kind investigated in the other. Fine-grained intention taxonomies developed in the philosophy of mind may be useful to identify the neural correlates of well-defined types of intentions, as well as to disentangle them from other related mental states, such as mere urges to perform an action. Intention-related neural signals may be exploited by brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) that are currently being developed to restore speech and motor control in paralyzed patients. Such BMI devices record the brain activity of the agent, interpret (\u201cdecode\u201d) the agent\u2019s intended action, and send the corresponding execution command to an artificial effector system, e.g., a computer cursor or a robotic arm. In the present paper, we evaluate the potential of intention concepts from philosophy of mind to improve the performance and safety of BMIs based on higher-order, intention-related control signals. To this end, we address the distinction between future-, present-directed, and motor intentions, as well as the organization of intentions in time, specifically to what extent it is sequential or hierarchical. This has consequences as to whether these different types of intentions can be expected to occur simultaneously or not. We further illustrate how it may be useful or even necessary to distinguish types of intentions exposited in philosophy, including yes- vs. no-intentions and oblique vs. direct intentions, to accurately decode the agent\u2019s intentions from neural signals in practical BMI applications.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Participants with severe TBI were also compared to controls on non-ToM inference tasks of indirect speech act from the Montreal Evaluation of Communication (M.E.C.) Protocol and empathy (Davis Interpersonal Reactivity Index - I.R.I.) and tests for executive functions. Subjects with TBI performed worse than control subjects on all ToM tasks, except the first-order false belief task. I define what I mean by intention\u2014 choice with commitment\u2014following prior work. Intention has a long history of research in some communities, and I offer one theoretical framework for modeling intention as a starting point.
